urn:contentItem:5WRP-Y9R1-JBJ9-H4K3-00000-00Deutsche Banken bündeln Payment-Angebote;Das Vorstandsmitglied über nationale und europäische Initiativen, Zugriff auf die Schnittstellen und Daten nach PSD2 und den Druck durch Big Tech2019-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:58ZLexisNexisIM INTERVIEW: THOMAS ULLRICH, DZ BANKS. 4Deutsche Banken bündeln Payment-AngeboteDas Vorstandsmitglied über nationale und europäische Initiativen, Zugriff auf die Schnittstellen und Daten nach PSD2 und den Druck durch Big TechKarin Böhmert

Börsen-Zeitung, 6.8.2019

- Herr Ullrich, im Zahlungsverkehr wird derzeit von verschiedenen Initiativen gesprochen, darunter #DK. Was hat es damit auf sich?

Es gibt aktuell zwei wichtige Initiativen im Zahlungsverkehr. Eine nationale, die unter dem Namen #DK (digitale Kreditwirtschaft) läuft, und eine europäische unter Federführung der französischen Banken. Ziel von #DK ist die säulenübergreifende Zusammenarbeit im Zahlungsverkehr.

- Und welches Ziel verfolgen die französischen Banken?

Die französischen Banken haben 18 internationale Institute zur sogenannten Pan-European Payment Solution eingeladen, wo über einen einheitlichen europäischen Zahlungsverkehr gesprochen wird. Im ersten Schritt soll Instant Payment als neuer Zahlungsverkehrsstandard etabliert werden.

- Dass Banken im europäischen Zahlungsverkehr so eng kooperieren, hat es seit Einführung des Euroschecks vor 50, 60 Jahren nicht mehr gegeben.

Das Thema ist auf höchster Führungsebene verankert: Bei allen Gesprächen auf europäischer Ebene - mit der Europäischen Zentralbank (EZB), den Nationalbanken und der Aufsicht - spricht die deutsche Kreditwirtschaft inzwischen mit einer Stimme.

- Woher kommt die plötzliche Erkenntnis, dass ein einheitlicher Zahlungsverkehr notwendig ist?

Die EU-Kommission und die Europäische Zentralbank sind treibende Kräfte. Hier setzt sich immer stärker die Ansicht durch, dass wir im europäischen Zahlungsverkehr der US-amerikanischen Dominanz etwas entgegensetzen müssen.

- Und in Deutschland?

Wir sprechen hierzu mit der Bundesbank und dem Bundesfinanzministerium. Denn Ziel einer Bündelung im Zahlungsverkehr ist, das Geschäftsmodell weiterzuentwickeln und damit Erträge für die deutsche Kreditwirtschaft zu sichern. Das ist ein wichtiges Thema, denn Kunden werden uns für Infrastruktur-Leistungen nicht mehr Geld zahlen. Erträge generieren wir künftig vor allem über kundenorientierte Zusatzleistungen und Vermittlungsprovisionen. Deswegen öffnen wir nun unsere Infrastruktur.

- Banken in Deutschland müssen also umdenken?

Ja, wir müssen anfangen, global zu denken. In diesem Punkt können wir von Big Techs lernen: Denken Amazon, Apple oder Google in nationalen Märkten? Nein, sie denken in weltweiten Dimensionen. #DK ist ein erster Schritt in diese Richtung und weg von einem zersplitterten Markt. Es kann aber nur ein erster Schritt sein, danach muss es zügig Richtung Europa gehen.

- Was konkret wollen Sie bündeln?

Wir erwägen, die bisherigen Lösungen in einem neuen Verfahren zusammenzufassen, dieses eng ans Girokonto zu koppeln und als ein Produkt über alle Kanäle anzubieten. Das ist die Idealvorstellung. In der deutschen Kreditwirtschaft ist und bleibt das Girokonto mit der Girocard der Ankerpunkt. Da diese jedoch nicht im E-Commerce verwendbar ist, haben wir Paydirekt und Giropay. Für die Person-to-Person-Zahlungen (P2P) bieten wir Kwitt sowie Paydirekt an.

- Wie wollen Sie Girocard, Paydirekt und Kwitt bündeln? Warum bündeln, wenn doch alles durch Instant Payment ersetzt wird?

Instant Payment ist die Langfristperspektive. Zunächst muss man sich auf ein Verfahren für P2P-Zahlungen einigen. Paydirekt ist gesetzt, muss sich aber stetig weiterentwickeln.

- Wie sieht der zeitliche Fahrplan aus?

Einen genauen Zeitplan kann ich Ihnen heute noch nicht nennen. Insgesamt brauchen wir für die Bündelung aber sicherlich zwei, drei Jahre.

- Wie soll die Vereinheitlichung des europäischen Zahlungsverkehrs technisch und organisatorisch funktionieren?

Wir haben gute Voraussetzungen, denn Instant Payment ist ein Sepa-Format, das für alle europäischen Banken gilt. Allerdings haben wir in Europa einen sehr unterschiedlichen Umsetzungs- und Einführungsgrad auf Länderebene. Hier besteht Handlungsbedarf, denn wir brauchen einen Standard in Europa, und zwar auf Basis von Instant Payment. Wenn wir das nicht schaffen, dann wird der Regulator uns das vorgeben. Davon bin ich überzeugt.

- Wenn Echtzeitüberweisungen europaweit zum "new normal" werden, was verändert sich dann konkret?

Der Kunde kann überall im E-Commerce und am Point of Sale (PoS) "instant" bezahlen. Noch hat im Online-Banking oder an der Ladenkasse jedes europäische Land andere Verfahren. Gegen diesen Flickenteppich hilft nur ein gemeinsamer Standard wie Instant Payment.

- Muss im Smartphone dann eigentlich noch eine Karte hinterlegt sein?

Perspektivisch nein, denn der Kunde bezahlt über sein Smartphone von Person zu Person, direkt an der Ladenkasse oder im Online-Shop. Ohne Karte, einfach über die Instant-Payment-Funktion, in Echtzeit.

- Ist das im Sinne des Kunden? Immerhin ist die 100 Millionen mal in Deutschland ausgegebene Girocard sehr beliebt. Würden die Menschen so einfach auf sie verzichten wollen?

Dass Kunden an der Girocard hängen, ist völlig berechtigt. Schließlich hat sie vielfach einen Zusatznutzen: man kann etwa Punkte mit ihr sammeln oder Mitgliedschaften auf der Karte hinterlegen. Fraglich ist jedoch, ob wir von der Grundstruktur noch eine Karte benötigen. Man braucht Instant für Europa und die Kreditkarte im Rest der Welt.

- Es gab in den letzten Jahrzehnten zahlreiche Anläufe, die Zahlungssysteme zusammenzuführen, darunter die dann gescheiterte Initiative Monnet, aus der die Franzosen ausgestiegen sind. Jetzt sollen die Franzosen Vorreiter sein und würden sogar ihre Carte bancaire aufgeben?

Ja, weil auch sie spüren, dass der Druck durch amerikanische Technologiekonzerne zunimmt. Wir alle spüren das. Wenn Sie mich vor einem Jahr gefragt hätten, ob die führenden Köpfe der deutschen Kreditwirtschaft die Bündelung ihrer Kräfte im Zahlungsverkehr planen würden, hätte ich das für wenig realistisch gehalten. Damals wäre es schlicht undenkbar gewesen, dass die Privatbankenmit den Sparkassen und Landesbanken sowie mit den Genossenschaftsinstituten so eng zusammenarbeiten.

- Früher sind gemeinschaftliche deutsche Initiativen durch kartellrechtliche Bedenken blockiert worden. Hat man im Kartellamt erkannt, dass der Wettbewerb im Internetzeitalter global stattfindet?

So ist das. Ich habe den Eindruck, dass es hier Bewegung gibt und das Bundeskartellamt schon heute immer stärker europäisch und global denkt.

- Wie kommen Echtzeitzahlungen bisher beim Kunden an?

Die genossenschaftlichen Institute wickeln derzeit durchschnittlich knapp 20 000 Transaktionen am Tag ab, mit einem durchschnittlichen Einzelumsatz von mehr als 700 Euro. Instant Payment wird also sehr gut angenommen, und das, obwohl wir erst am Anfang stehen und die Banken noch lernen, mit dem neuen Verfahren umzugehen.

- Ist die Betragsgrenze ein Hindernis?

Es gibt Überlegungen, die aktuelle Betragsgrenze von 15 000 Euro auf 100 000 Euro zu erhöhen. Das wäre eine echte Verbesserung, vor allem für Firmenkunden. Gerade für sie ist Instant Payment eine Chance. Das Geld ist binnen von Sekunden auf dem Konto, und das inklusive sämtlicher Geldwäsche- und Compliance-Prüfungen.

- Was ist mit den Privatkunden, die ihre Girocards gewohnt sind? Gehen die in den Supermarkt, halten ihr Smartphone ans Terminal und zahlen mobil?

Hier müssen wir unterscheiden zwischen dem mobilen Bezahlen in der App, beispielsweise über Google Pay oder Apple Pay, und dem kontaktlosen Bezahlen. Unsere Kunden präferieren klar Letzteres. Dabei halten sie ihre Karte ans Terminal - bis 25 Euro geht das sogar ohne PIN-Eingabe. Bis Jahresende stellen wir alle unsere Karten auf kontaktlos um. Im Vergleich dazu wird das Mobile Banking bisher verhalten angenommen.

- Können Sie Zahlen nennen?

Die Genossenschaftsbanken haben 30 Millionen Girocards ausgegeben, über 20 Millionen davon sind kontaktlos, und gut 150 000 sind digital, also für Google Pay auf Android-Geräten freigeschaltet. Im Mai wurden Girocard-Transaktionen mit einem Volumen von 4 Mrd. Euro kontaktlos getätigt. Das ist viel, und ich rechne mit einer weiteren Steigerung.

- Bei Apple Pay waren Sie zurückhaltend mit Blick auf den Datenschutz. Haben Sie sich nun geeinigt?

Ja, wir haben uns geeinigt. Im Laufe des Jahres werden die Genossenschaftsbanken ihren Kunden Apple Pay anbieten.

- Wie wird sich das mobile Bezahlen Ihrer Meinung nach weiterentwickeln?

Es wird sich zeigen, bei welchen Verfahren sich die Investitionen rechnen. Bei der Kontaktlos-Technologie bin ich sehr zuversichtlich. Wenn man sich die Liste der populärsten Smartphone-Bezahlverfahren anschaut, so hat Apple Pay nach einer aktuellen Studie der Postbank noch Potenzial.

- Wie weit sind Sie mit den Vorbereitungen für die Umsetzung der Zahlungsdiensterichtlinie PSD2, die am 14. September greift?

Bei PSD2 geht es um zwei Aspekte: Erstens um die "starke Authentifizierung", auch Zwei-Faktor-Authentifizierung genannt. Diese betrifft das Zahlen mit Kreditkarte. Der zweite Teil der Richtlinie betrifft den Zugriff von Dritten auf Informationen von Kundenkonten. Aktuell hakt es noch an einigen Stellen, gerade bei der Zwei-Faktor-Authentifizierung. Zwar haben die Banken ihre Kunden umfassend darüber informiert, dass sie bis September ihre Sicherheitsmerkmale für Online-Einkäufe festlegen und ihre Kreditkarte freischalten müssen. Ein großer Teil der Kunden hat dies auch bereits getan. Jedoch sind viele Händler noch nicht in der Lage, die neuen Technologien anzuwenden. Der Handel wartet auf Spezifikationen, die der Regulator erst spät herausgegeben hat.

- Die Standards (Regulatory Technical Standards, RTS) sind doch schon beschlossen?

Ja, aber bis sie umgesetzt werden können, dauert es. Stand heute haben noch keine 50 % unserer Kreditkartennutzer eine Freischaltung fürs E-Commerce. Unsere Sorge ist, dass viele Kunden am 14. September im Internet einkaufen wollen und das nicht funktionieren wird. Deswegen hat die europäische Aufsicht EBA den nationalen Aufsichtsbehörden nun vorgeschlagen, den 14. September nicht als hartes Datum zu sehen, sondern Flexibilität zu gewähren. Fest steht: Die Marktteilnehmer tun alles, um die PSD2-Anforderungen pünktlich umzusetzen, aber die Komplexität ist nicht zu unterschätzen.

- Das ist aber nur ein Teil der PSD2, wo stehen Sie mit dem zweiten?

Der zweite Teil betrifft den Kontozugriff durch Dritte. Das Problem ist, dass es derzeit keine einheitliche europäische Schnittstelle gibt. Deshalb setzt sich beispielsweise die Initiative "Berlin Group" dafür ein, diese Schnittstelle zu harmonisieren, und zwar banken- und länderübergreifend. Dazu hat sie den "NextGenPSD2"-Standard ins Leben gerufen, worunter man eine Reihe moderner, offener, harmonisierter und untereinander kompatibler Programmierschnittstellen versteht. Darüber sollen Daten sicher bereitgestellt werden können.

- Fintechs werfen den Banken vor, die Schnittstellen zu blockieren. Stimmt das?

Die Banken blockieren die Schnittstelle nicht, sie halten sich lediglich streng an die Regeln der PSD2. Das bedeutet in der Konsequenz, dass weniger Daten als früher zur Verfügung gestellt werden dürfen. Die bisherige Schnittstelle, die Fintechs genutzt haben, hat Zugriff auf viel mehr Daten ermöglicht.

- Was genau bekommen Drittanbieter jetzt nicht mehr?

Fintechs leben von der Datenanalyse. Bislang war es so: Wenn Kunden ihre Bankanwendungen geöffnet hatten, konnten Drittanbieter Daten direkt auslesen. Unter PSD2 funktioniert dieses Screen Scraping nicht mehr. Das wird der Fintech-Community erst jetzt richtig bewusst. Das wird noch eine spannende Diskussion, die auf uns zukommt und der wir uns gerne stellen.

- Wurde das bisher nicht getestet?

Seit Mai gibt es die sogenannte Sandbox zum Testen. Bei der DZ Bank hat jedoch noch kein Firmenkunde oder Fintech im Hinblick auf die Nutzung der PSD2-Schnittstelle angefragt. Anders sieht es bei den Genossenschaftsbanken aus, die eine verhaltene Nachfrage nach dem Testen über die Sandbox verzeichnen. Meine Prognose ist, dass auf diese PSD2-Schnittstelle wahrscheinlich nur die großen Technologieunternehmen zugreifen wollen, um ihren Datenpool zu erweitern. Alle anderen, die die Schnittstelle nutzen könnten, wie Händler oder Firmenkunden, haben bislang überhaupt kein Interesse an den Daten und deren Analyse.

- Was erwarten Fintechs speziell?

Bei der PSD2 werden nur Girokontodaten zur Verfügung gestellt. Möglicherweise wird mit der nächsten Richtlinie nach PSD2 die Schnittstelle auch auf Datentöpfe, wie zum Beispiel Depotdaten, erweitert. Hier sagen die Regulatoren aber, dass Fintechs und Technologieunternehmen für mehr Daten auch mehr zahlen müssen. Vielleicht nicht in Euro, sondern ebenfalls in Daten, soll heißen: Sie müssten ihre Daten ebenfalls bereitstellen.

- Was erwarten Sie am 14. September von den Tech-Unternehmen?

Die Technologiefirmen werden zunächst abwarten, wie sich alles einspielt. Gerade im Hinblick auf den zuvor erwähnten flexiblen Start-Termin der PSD2.

- Zumal der Kunde dem Zugriff auf seine Daten zustimmen muss.

Das ist der nächste Punkt. Wir bieten unseren Kunden ein Steuerungscockpit im Online-Banking an, das Zugriffe von außen dokumentiert. Die Bank kann entweder vorgeben, wie viele Tage sie die Zugriffsmöglichkeit bereitstellen will, und nach diesem Zeitraum muss der Kunde jeden Zugriff genehmigen. Oder sie kann festlegen, dass der Kunde jede Zugriffsanfrage freigeben muss. Wenn wir also feststellen, dass die Technologiekonzerne regelmäßig Daten abgreifen, können wir mit dem Einverständnis des Kunden den Zugriff beschränken.

- Apropos Big Techs: muss der Regulator nicht ein viel stärkeres Auge auf die Tech-Konzerne haben als auf die Fintechs?

Das ist richtig. Die Big Techs werden schneller Tatsachen schaffen, als der Regulator Bedingungen formuliert. Das sehen wir doch gerade bei der Diskussion um die neue Facebook-Währung Libra, alle stehen Kopf. Dass Libra auch direkt bei einem G7-Gipfel diskutiert wird, verdeutlicht die Brisanz dieses Themas.

- Libra will rund 1,7 Milliarden Menschen Zugang zum Finanzsystem verschaffen, die heute keinen haben, insbesondere in der dritten Welt. Das ist doch ein positiver Antritt?

Natürlich kann eine Chance in so einer Währung liegen. Facebooks Vision ist, dass diese Menschen durch ihr Smartphone und Facebook Zugang zu einer Bankverbindung bekommen. Und die Libra soll mit einem Staatsanleihenkorb unterlegt werden. Im Gegensatz zu Kryptowährungen wie Bitcoin hat Libra den Vorteil, dass sie keine starken Kursschwankungen erleben dürfte. Das ist eine der zentralen Herausforderungen auf dem Weg zu einem stabilen Online-Zahlungsmittel. Spannend wird es, wenn Facebook über die Phase der Ankündigung hinauskommt. Dann muss man sich auch genau anschauen, welche Pläne das Unternehmen beim Thema Verbraucher- und Datenschutz hat. Diesbezüglich gab es bisher ja vor allem negative Schlagzeilen.

- Wie sollte sich der Regulator hier verhalten? Sollte er die Entwicklung von Libra aufhalten?

Den Schritt vom Bargeld und Buchgeld zum virtuellen Geld ist vor dem Hintergrund allgegenwärtiger Digitalisierung schon fast eine logische Konsequenz - umso wichtiger ist, dass dieser Prozess reguliert und kontrolliert abläuft. Weder Politik noch Bürger können ein Interesse daran haben, dass Monopolisten entstehen. Das gilt auch bei digitalen Währungen. Ich mache mir große Sorgen, dass das Thema Datenschutz und Datensicherheit in einem bisher nicht regulierten, von Facebook entwickelten Framework vernachlässigt wird.

- Wer wäre der Regulator für Libra?

Mit Libra müssten sich die europäischen, amerikanischen und asiatischen Bankaufsichtsbehörden befassen. Das Thema ist bei den G7- oder G20-Staatschefs schon richtig aufgehoben. Vor allem wird es auf ein abgestimmtes und geschlossenes Handeln der Behörden ankommen. Nur so kann man einem global agierenden Unternehmen sinnvoll begegnen.

- Was müssten die Aufseher bei Libra beachten?

Die größte Herausforderung für die Aufseher ist sicher, dass keine Erfahrungswerte bezüglich der Regulierung digitaler Währungen vorliegen. Also muss man sich viele Fragen zum ersten Mal stellen. Um beim Beispiel Libra zu bleiben: Was passiert, wenn Facebook eines Tages nicht mehr existiert? Wie wird Wertstabilität garantiert, wie Geldwäsche verhindert? Ich habe Bedenken, dass der Regulator zu spät reagiert, indem er sich dazu nicht rechtzeitig positioniert.

----

Das Interview führte Karin Böhmert.

urn:contentItem:5SXT-SK31-DY0W-44S7-00000-00Devastation in California; Pence on GDP & Tariffs; U.S. Manufacturers Charging More As Metal, Aluminum Tariffs Take Effect; Senator Graham Threatens WTO Withdrawal if China's Behavior Does Not Change; Nunes (R-CA) Considering Legal Action Over Twitter's Shadow Banning; Moonves Investigation; Tesla's $1,500 Surf Board Sold Out; One Strike Short Of No- Hitter; Kyle Busch Wins Sixth Race; Johnson Wins Canadian Open; Six Head To Cooperstown2018-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:59ZLexisNexisDevastation in California; Pence on GDP & Tariffs; U.S. Manufacturers Charging More As Metal, Aluminum Tariffs Take Effect; Senator Graham Threatens WTO Withdrawal if China's Behavior Does Not Change; Nunes (R-CA) Considering Legal Action Over Twitter's Shadow Banning; Moonves Investigation; Tesla's $1,500 Surf Board Sold Out; One Strike Short Of No- Hitter; Kyle Busch Wins Sixth Race; Johnson Wins Canadian Open; Six Head To CooperstownLanhamFULL TEXT

TRACEE CARRASCO, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: But right now, let's send it over to MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Cheryl Casone in for Maria Bartiromo. Cheryl, you are a busy woman this morning.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I am. And Tracee, as are you. Fun having FBN:AM with you today. Of course, Tracee, thank you so much.

CARRASCO: Thank you.

CASONE: Yes, good morning everybody. I'm Cheryl Casone, I'm in for Maria Bartiromo today. It is Monday, July 30th and your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern Time.

Tech stocks in focus, Apple reporting after tomorrow's close and it comes after last week's tech wreck on Wall Street. We're going to be looking at the earnings effect on your markets.

Investors also eyeing the economy, Maria speaking to Vice President Mike Pence in an exclusive interview, weighing in on the state of the economy after Friday's GDP report driven by a surge and, yes, exports.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Whether we'll see those dramatic increase in business investment, a dramatic increase in American exports all support the conclusion that the policies that President Trump has been advancing that a republican congress have been supporting are actually working to revive this economy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, checking the markets to start your new week. Right now Futures pointing to a little bit of a mixed (INAUDIBLE). The Dow is up five points in the premarket, S&P is down by two, and the NASDAQ, tech- heavy NASDAQ down by 11 and three quarters.

This is all after a down day on Friday yet weakness in the tech sector weighing in on the rest of the market. That is Friday's close. And as you can see, it was, again, the NASDAQ that took the biggest hit, down almost one and a half percent on Friday.

Now, let's take a look at Europe, modest declines there, not too bad. The FTSE, the CAC40, the DAX are all in the red. And then taking a look at Asia overnight, we did see declines across the board. As you can see, the Nikkei down. Biggest lost there, down three quarters of a percent.

Well, devastation in California, deadly wildfires are spreading rapidly across the northern part of the state. We're going to take you there for the latest on the battle against that raging and deadly blaze.

And uncertainty this morning at CBS, the company's board is looking at CEO Les Moonves's future amid sexual harassment allegations. The details coming up later on this hour.

And a big win at Pocono, Kyle Busch coming from behind for his sixth win of the season, but a scary scene on the track after Bubba Wallace, ooh, crashed. Ouch.

And then on the links we go, Dustin Johnson coming out on top of the RBC Canadian Open joining elite company with his 19th career victory. We're going to have all those sports highlights coming up for you during this hour.

And then from the road to the sea, Elon Musk is now offering Tesla branded surfboards and they're already out. Oh yes.

All of that coming up. And with me this morning, I got a great panel this morning, Republican Strategist Erin Elmore is with me this morning. FOX Business Network's Adam Shapiro. And Maslansky & Partners President Lee Carter. Boy, I'm a lucky girl today, good morning.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

ERIN ELMORE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Good morning.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Good morning. We're lucky to have you.

CASONE: Where -- it's -- where to start? I mean, Adam, I can't wait for Tesla. I'm like this.

SHAPIRO: Are you going to go surfing?

CASONE: Oh, no. No. Anything with Elon Musk's name. But, yes, all these big Dow components today and the economy in trade, it's going to be great.

SHAPIRO: Yes. And then we've got Apple coming up and that's going to be - - Apple's tomorrow as a matter of fact, so it's going to be interesting to see how Mr. Cook responds to whether the -- was the iPhone X.

CASONE: Yes.

SHAPIRO: You know, you don't see a lot of advertising for the X right now.

CASONE: Yes. And we're so used Erin obviously to having these big iPhone announcements, but investors --

ELMORE: Right.

CASONE: -- are kind of thinking, "No, not so great anymore."

ELMORE: I need a new one, I know that much. But they're saying that the new one is like they're going to come out in September which they did help for fourth quarter, so that should be an interesting fourth quarter.

CASONE: Well we have a lot to get to this morning. Our top story this hour, yes, second quarter earnings continuing. You've got five Dow components reporting this week starting with Caterpillar today and followed by Pfizer, P&G, Apple, and Dow DuPont. Those are all coming up in the days ahead as we're just talking about it.

Now this is coming on the hills of a tumble in technology stocks after Facebook results disappointed investors last week leading the company to lose $119 billion in market value in just one day. This marks the biggest market cap decline in a single day in market history.

All right. So after the big meltdown that we had with Facebook Adam, we were just talking about it a little bit. But the bigger story for Apple obvious is going to be the iPhone sale.

SHAPIRO: It's going to -- it is going to be iPhone sales, it's always iPhone sales. But it's going to be interesting to see -- they were never going to be in jeopardy with tariffs in China because finished product is not being -- there's not a tariff imposed on finished product.

But it's going to be interesting to see if they address this issue because the Chinese can retaliate against the United States by cracking down on companies that are reliant on Chinese producers for components. It's going to be interesting to see if they do weigh in on that.

CASONE: You know, and also Lee, you know, you can tell by your polling I'm sure that if prices start to really creep up on the U.S. consumers whether it's Apple, whether it's Harley-Davidson, their (INAUDIBLE) products, that's going to have an impact on the politic side of this.

CARTER: It is going to have an impact on the politics side of this. I think it's really important though that the president had that victory with Europe last week because I think people were really starting to concern -- get concerned about trade.

For a long time, more than two-thirds of Americans were saying we're willing to say that we believe that these tariffs are negotiating strategy by the president. We don't think it's going to have a long-term impact on us.

So he needed to have a win to try and keep those concerns at bay as the midterms are coming up because if people start to feel it in their pocket book in whatever the case is, it's going to be hard for the republicans to say this is a good strategy.

CASONE: Erin, that's a really good point. The midterms is going to be all about the economy, is it going to -- is there going to be a good or bad story?

ELMORE: Right. Because what Trump sees is a long play and when you have a midterm election of such significance and importance, long plays really don't work.

But he is a businessman, we know the art of the deal, he is the art of the deal, this is a way like he showed with his meetings in Europe to squeeze these people and say, "Hey, I promised you on the campaign trail in 2016 that I was going to make things fair for America, NAFTA included."

And we're all starting to see these things happen in change. So the long play, maybe shortened and the midterms could be saved, we have to wait and see.

SHAPIRO: But to Lee's point about people filling in their pocket book, there are people in the country who are being asked to take a greater sacrifice during these negotiations and that's the farmers.

And, yes, there's $12 billion to assist but we export $140 billion with agriculture products future, $12 billion is not going to carry these men and women very far for very long. And they are not happy, they are very -- I mean, look at the Des Moines Register, $642 million loss just because of soybean and it's not just soybean that's taking a hit, it's corn, you saw the story about beef piling up in freezers.

CARTER: Oh yes.

CASONE: Yes.

SHAPIRO: This -- you know, we have an election cycle every two years, the Chinese don't have the same kind of pressure on them to react.

CARTER: That's right.

CASONE: Well obviously this interview that Maria had with the vice president made a lot of news. You know, Vice President Pence did tout the Trump Administration's economic progress.

And he denied that that part of the GDP growth was due to foreign buyers stocking up on American products like Adam was just talking about soybeans before retaliatory tariffs go into place.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PENCE: The reality is in the last two administrations, the economy grew by less than two percent and in the first 18 months of this administration.

We were a little shy of three percent last year, we're on track to be at three percent or better this year. And --

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: How much of this quarter was goosed by businesses trying to get ahead of the president's tariff?

PENCE: So we think we're seeing real progress, we don't think this was an anomaly. We think American exports are on the rise as a reflection of a strong economy and frankly, a reflection of the president's strong leadership on improving our trade relationships for American jobs and American workers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Lee, what is your reaction to his comment? And this is all about at the end of the day even if it's a little bit messy, it's about the American worker, that is their focus.

CARTER: That is right. And I've got to say that this messaging, this focus on getting people come to the long-term strategy but also this message that we're fighting for the American people, putting America first.

I think it set people up to believe this is what's going to happen. They (INAUDIBLE), they keep seeing these kinds of things, they see the growth, they see the markets, they see their 401(k) and IRA is growing.

And what they're going to think right now is, "You know what, I'm willing to take a bet on some of these things that I'm not agreeing with." And let's be very, very clear, a lot of voters out there are saying there's certain things about this president that make me very uncomfortable.

But when I look at the members, when I look at my balance, when I look at tax reform, when I look at growth on the economy, I'm willing to take it.

CASONE: Yes. And Erin, you know, James Carville said (INAUDIBLE) that famous quote that the economy is stupid, that quote still rings true today.

ELMORE: At the end of the day, I think -- and Lee will probably know him better than I. But the average American isn't worrying about Stormy Daniels and all of these controversies, they're worrying about paying their bills and sending their kids to school, and making sure that their taxes are within range.

And the American people really do care about that and the economy is working as (INAUDIBLE) said himself.

CASONE: But what is interesting thing there -- I love -- I love James Carville. But, you know, the same that if you look at what the Chinese are doing, they're targeting Trump states, they are targeting his base to put pressure on him to back off of them. That's the Chinese strategy, but does it work?

SHAPIRO: Well that's what the Chinese are doing when you see them retaliate against agriculture in the Midwest.

But the other question, if the tax cuts are so beneficial as republicans are saying, why are some republicans not using that on the campaign trail with their constituents? I mean, democrats will point out the thousand dollar bonuses that a lot of people got were not pay increases. You must got the bonus but not the raise.

CASONE: Nancy Pelosi called them crumbs. Yes. Come on.

CARTER: See, that polled well rightly.

CASONE: Yes.

CARTER: That was -- that was the soundbyte that kept (INAUDIBLE)

CASONE: Well, you know, Nancy Pelosi came out back in May. Remember she kind of hinted that the democrats took back the House that she would push a rollback to tax cuts? I mean, really?

SHAPIRO: Well, good luck trying to get that done. But you can expect to hear from the democrats, you're going to hear we're going to have a trillion dollar deficit. And -- but the republican said is the tax cuts would pay for themselves overtime and what you're hearing different people in the administration is.

I think it was Kudlow who said on Friday, we're going to need another year or two to ramp up to the point where we grow ourselves out of these deficits.

CASONE: A lot of officials were out over the weekend in particular talking to the media. You had Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin saying that he sees a period of sustained GDP growth over the next several years, listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. TREASURY SECRETARY: We can only project a couple of years in the future. But I think we're well on this path for several years, so I don't -- I don't think this is a one or two-year phenomenon. I think we definitely are in a period of four or five years of sustained three percent growth at least.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Sustained three percent. Adam, is that realistic you think?

SHAPIRO: It's a simple answer. Yes, I do think it's realistic simply because of what the tax cut did lowering the corporate tax rate down to 21 percent and conceivably putting more money into the pockets of more Americans that --

CASONE: Sure.

SHAPIRO: Yes. I think you're going to see that overtime. Five years? I hope so.

CASONE: Yes. That would be nice, right?

CARTER: That would be really nice.

ELMORE: That's what the president says he foresee.

CASONE: Yes. Well that's what Steven Mnuchin said on FOX News Sunday Lee. And I mean, you know, again, there's no reason at this point not to think that the, you know, three, four, five percent GDP growth overtime is -- was attainable. I mean, the companies are doing really well right now.

CARTER: Companies are --

CASONE: (INAUDIBLE) still doing.

CARTER: Companies are doing really well, earnings are going really well outside of some of these techs. But they have their own reasons for it. So I think those are kind of -- you know, there should be a distraction from what the larger methods is.

And I think by enlarge the American people are very optimistic about the future right now. They feel good, they feel these things. Now I think, you know, Adam to your point about the farmers and, you know, China going after the red states, I think that's significant.

But I think that the president has done so much laying that foundation that people understand it might be hard to get winds in the long-term. And as long as they see small victories along the way, I think they're going to be willing to stick with them. I don't know how long but I think they're going to be willing to stick with them for some period of time.

SHAPIRO: The only thing I would say to that is it's easy for us who don't rely on income based on selling agriculture to ask other people to stick it out. And I realized the $12 million supplements are designed to help folks.

But as 330 million of us in the United States are not being asked to make the sacrifice that thousands of men and women who are farmers are being asked. And how long you can ask that of just a small portion of the population for these negotiations, we'll see.

CASONE: Trade, not aid. We've heard that phrase so many times down the last week. Well we're going to be bringing you much more of Maria's exclusive interview with Vice President Mike Pence.

That's going to be coming up on the show including, this is cool, a never before seen look inside the vice president's office at the White House. Just a sneak peak for you.

All right. Coming up, the ferocious wildfires in California have killed a woman and her two great grandchildren. Officials believe at least seven people are missing as they continue to battle this monster blaze.

And Tesla creating surfboards with the same materials as its cars, we're going to tell you how much the now sold out boards are going for.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: All right. Dow Futures searching for a little bit of direction on this Monday. Right now the Dow itself is up by five points in the premarket, S&P is down one and three quarters, NASDAQ is down 12 and three quarters. Tech-heavy NASDAQ maybe crucial again to watch this week.

Well, wildfires causing death and destruction in northern California. Thousands flee their homes as the blaze charge nearly 150 square miles. FOX News Correspondent Lauren Blanchard is live in Redding, California with the latest. It's been a rough night for them Lauren, good morning.

LAUREN BLANCHARD, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, good morning Cheryl. And we are in front of what is left of a home here in Redding. An entire neighborhood left nearly in ashes.

Now the car fire has destroyed about 650 homes so far burning nearly 100,000 acres. Fire official say they've been able to contain 17 percent of the fire, that's up from only five percent Sunday morning. But they say this fire is uniquely tough to stop. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGER MOORE, REDDING POLICE DEPARTMENT: With the intensity that we have here, it's really hard to stop and move -- fast moving wind-driven fire.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This fire is scary to us. This is something we haven't seen before in the city.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BLANCHARD: The car fire fueled by strong winds and dry bushes killed four civilians and two firefighters. A grandmother and her two young grandchildren killed when the fire quickly spread to their home.

Plus, another person discovered Sunday and the car fire is just one of more than a dozen fires burning in California. Another firefighter killed Sunday battling the fire in Yosemite National Park.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is fire is -- has not mercy, this is everywhere.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well I've had a few friends whose house are already --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BLANCHARD: And more than 3,300 firefighters are battling the car fire alone, there are about 12,000 firefighters around the state of California also working to tap down on the number of those fires.

We have seen reports and seen stories of volunteers using their trucks and (INAUDIBLE) to help move livestock as well as help those families who are fleeing their homes, Cheryl.

CASONE: And some -- especially with some of those firefighters themselves losing their homes as they battle those fires, it's incredible. Lauren Blanchard. Lauren, thank you very much.

We've got a lot more coming up. A possible shakeup at CBS to tell you about, the board could decide today on whether or not CEO Les Moonves to step aside amid sexual harassment allegations. We've got details on why the probe could go far beyond the company's chief.

And after a bumpy ride from other tech giants, investors are looking for some sweet news from Apple earnings tomorrow. We're going to have a preview for you, we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: Well, big technology on tap this morning. Apple set to release their earnings tomorrow after the close. The company's second quarter report follows disappointing numbers from its fellow tech titan.

Facebook last week wiping out all of its 2018 gains imposing the largest one-day loss in market value by any company in history following a disastrous quarterly report. Twitter also taking a hit from a decline in monthly users, that stock went plummeting.

Let's bring in Jonathan Hoenig, Capitalist Pig.com Founder. Oh man, I'll tell you, it was a rough week for technology Jonathan last week, all of it on earnings.

JONATHAN HOENIG, FOUNDER, CAPITALIST PIG.COM: Yes, they're brutal.

CASONE: Let's --

HOENIG: Yes, (INAUDIBLE). I haven't seen anything like it.

CASONE: I know. I feel like we should move on and talk about Apple and try to put last week behind into Facebook and Twitter but let's talk about Apple's report. Do you think that's actually going to help the sector turn itself around?

HOENIG: Let's hope so. Let's hope so Cheryl because as you pointed out the bloodbath in the NASDAQ last week almost like something that we really haven't seen certainly since the election.

I mean, since the election technology stocks like Apple have accounted for about half the market's total gain. So these big cap stocks, the Netflixes, the Apples, the Tesla also reporting earnings this week. These have been the drivers of the market.

So, of course, investors are going to be listening very closely not only about the prospect of a new phone, we've heard that, of course, hinted from Apple's conference calls but also about the prospect of growth in their cloud business.

You know, the iPhone still counts for 62 percent of Apple sales but that's almost the old news. The new news for Apple in terms of earnings is the cloud. But Cheryl, to your original point, given the damage in tech stocks last week, I think a lot of investors are just going to be hoping to get through this earning season without any more major blowups like Tesla and like Twitter.

SHAPIRO: Jonathan hey, it's Adam Shapiro. I wanted to pick up on something you said about, you know, the -- as they shift towards the cloud because we saw what Amazon did with their web services blew everyone away.

On the women's side, 2017 champion Ekaterina Makarova hasn't reached the quarterfinal in the whole of 2018, but the Russian did reach the round of 16 at Wimbledon. And here's an innovation to keep an eye on in D.C. A new shot clock will be on courts limiting players to just 25 seconds between points.

And don't forget, Tennis Channel's exclusive live coverage of the Citi Open starts Monday at 2:30 p.m. Eastern. For court report, I'm Dani Klupenger.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: And welcome back. I'm Cheryl Casone, in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Monday, July 30th, your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern time. Another big week for earnings; Caterpillar releasing better-than-expected earnings this morning. The stock getting a big boost to the premarket up almost 3- 1/2 percent. Other big names this week from the Dow, Proctor & Gamble, Pfizer, Dell, DuPont, and Apple, all reporting.

Now, Apple is going to report their earnings tomorrow; everybody's watching after last week's lackluster reports from Facebook and from Twitter. Right now, all of those stocks, though, in the premarket are slightly higher.

All right. Let's take a look for it if we can at what's happening in your premarket, and of course, what's happening over in Europe. First, the U.S. futures, everything is now in the green, and that's a little bit of an improvement what we've seen over the last hour. Dow pointing to the premarket, S&P up a half point; NASDAQ up 2-1/2.

Now, in Europe, a little bit of a different story. It's been a mixed bag, though, for most sessions so far. The FTSE is slightly higher. CAC Quarante and DAX are actually in the red. And all the Asian markets actually finished lower. Japan's Nikkei, the biggest hit losing about three-quarters of a percent there.

Well, President Trump thanking North Korean Leader Kim Jong-un for returning the remains of missing U.S. soldiers from the Korean War. In her exclusive interview, Maria asked vice President Mike Pence what he thought of the president's work with North Korea.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PENCE: The fact that this president sitting down with Kim Jong-un to negotiate the complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, also had fallen heroes on his heart, should tell you everything you need to know about President Donald Trump.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: We're going to have more from Maria's exclusive interview and emotional interview, that's coming up. And you won't want to miss our never-before-seen look inside the vice president's office in White House, where he shares his father's bronze star.

Well, it is a black eye for CBS. The network's board of directors preparing an investigation into allegations that CEO, Les Moonves, sexually harassed women. We've got those details.

And Venmo, is one of the go-to apps for sending money, but the company may be sharing all of your transactions. We're going to tell you, how you protect yourself.

And check this out, touching video of a father coming to aid for his daughter. Wait until you see what he did for her and what caused her to react that way.

All right. Topping our news this half-hour: President Donald Trump threatening a government shutdown, if Congress does not find money for the border wall and make world changes to the immigration laws. Blake Burman live at the White House with the details. Blake, good morning.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Cheryl, good morning to you. You might remember earlier this summer, it was the president himself who suggested to Republicans that they wait until after the November election to tackle immigration. Well, now, it appears as if the president has a new summertime demand himself because this is a tweet that he fired off over the weekend, writing: "I would be willing to shut down government, if the Democrats do not give us the votes for border security, which includes the wall. Must get rid of lottery, catch-and- release, et cetera, and finally go to system of immigration based on merit. We need great people coming into our country." The Republican Senator Ron Johnson immediately after that tweet was sent off, sounded leery.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. RON JOHNSON (R), WISCONSIN: I certainly don't like playing shut down politics.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And how damaging would that be for Republicans ahead of the November races?

JOHNSON: I don't think it'd be helpful, so let's try and avoid it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The Democratic Congresswoman Maxine Waters described it as nothing more than a scare tactic.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MAXINE WATERS (D), CALIFORNIA: This president is a bully, and he'll try and intimidate all of us. He's not going to shut down anything. He's not going to shut down the government, and we're not going to be intimidated by his bluffing and his bullying.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now, any immigration measure would need Democrat support. Before that tweet was sent over the weekend, the Vice President Mike expressed to Maria his frustration of Democrats not getting behind the president's agenda.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PENCE: It is amazing to think just as an aside Maria, that, that in the last year and a half, our administration has faced more filibusters called by Chuck Schumer and the Democrats in the Senate, by a factor of four times more than any administration going all the way back to the Carter administration.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: All right, Cheryl. So, when you look at the calendar to see how all this might play out, September 30th is the deadline for a new spending bill -- just 60 days from today. And after that, five weeks after that, comes the November election, of how all of that might fit into you puzzle. Cheryl.

CASONE: And a Supreme Court nomination as well. Blake Burman --

BURMAN: And whatever else comes between now and then, too, right?

CASONE: No kidding. Blake Burman live at the White House. Blake, thank you very much. Well, let's switch gears now. Maria Bartiromo is taking us inside the White House for a behind closed doors look at Vice President Mike Pence's West Wing office, where he continues to help carry out President Trump's agenda. Let's watch.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PENCE: In the room.

BARTIROMO: Oh, gosh, that is gorgeous.

PENCE: And this is my wall (INAUDIBLE), because this is my first time -- and these are two of my favorite --

BARTIROMO: Beautiful. And you said you have your father's bronze star here.

PENCE: I do. This is, actually, my dad receiving the bronze star.

BARTIROMO: Oh, wow! Beautiful.

PENCE: And this is the medal.

BARTIROMO: I can understand why it's so important for you to go and meet with those families.

PENCE: Well.

BARTIROMO: Thank you to your father for serving our country. I know he is gone --

PENCE: Well, he's gone 30 years but he's still in our hearts every day, and I know he was incredibly proud of his service and the Korean War. And when Karen and I made our first trip to the region, I was so deeply moved because as we traveled around South Korea, there were signs with my father's name on them; posters that been put up saying: "Tell your father, Edward Pence thank you for your service." So, the name will be there, and -- be a part of a homecoming for those heroes.

BARTIROMO: Even though, a long time ago, it will be closure for some people, right?

PENCE: There's no question. My father, had he lived would be in just in his late 80s now, and he's U.S. Army infantry combat veteran. And I know this is going to be meaningful to other Korean War veterans, it's going to be meaningful to every veteran, and frankly, every family, who, I think, sees President Trump's heart in this moment.

BARTIROMO: Why did Kim Jong-un agree to it?

PENCE: Because President Trump asked him. And that is -- it's so moving to me, to serve alongside a president while he is negotiating an issue as significant as denuclearization on the Korean Peninsula, where he's taken such a strong stand for America's security. That at the same time, he had our fallen heroes on his heart, and he's secured a commitment in Hawaii next week. We'll see North Korea begin to follow through on the promise that they made to President Trump.

BARTIROMO: Wow. It will be an emotional week for you. Thank you.

PENCE: Great.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much.

PENCE: Thanks.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CASONE: What a great tour of his office with Maria. Lee, let me ask you, what was your biggest takeaway this morning from the interview that we've been playing.

CARTER: You know, I think there's a few things. One, when you look at this man, he is such a balance to our president -- where he is very calm. The president is really, you know, I don't know, what bombastic. He's just -- they're just totally opposite but complementary to each other. So, you look at this and you think, you feel reassured. I also feel that the way he talked about the president's agend, the policy, you can really see that he supports the economic growth, the jobs; why they're doing the things they are doing?

And I think that you can see that you can separate the man -- I think, you know, Herman Cain said this earlier: "You can separate the man from agenda." And that's what the vice president does so well. It really points out what they're accomplishing: The jobs, the economy, what they're doing on trade. It really goes are great inside, but to how he thinks and that balance is working out there.

CASONE: That's interesting. Erin?

ERIN ELMORE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: I just see when I watch him, his authenticity. And you can see someone who truly cares about our country and honestly making it great again. He's so proud of the president's agenda. He's proud that, you know, unemployment is low, and things are going well in terms of we're working on NAFTA. He touched on all of those things, that Donald Trump was pushing in 2016, and now that are coming to fruition. And just to see him talk about those, you can see his -- just sincerity and how proud he is to be an American to be doing this civil service job.

CASONE: Yes, he does seem to -- and I love his faith. I love how much his faith drives him in his life, and his wife as well.

CARTER: His family.

SHAPIRO: The thing that I'm ruminating over here, though, is the president's threat of a shutdown on immigration, and on the spending bill. And we saw the Republican who, on the Sunday talk shows said, this is not the fight to pick in the fall in September. What I keep thinking is: Republicans have the majority in the House, so they don't need Democrats. You need the 60 votes in the Senate, however, you know the president has been calling to get rid of the filibuster, Mitch McConnell has said he doesn't want to go there, but is something going on president now threatening, you know, let's bring on shutdown if we don't get what we want.

CASONE: Well, he wants the border -- I mean, not only the president who wants that wall. I mean, he campaigned on wall; immigration is a major issue in this country no matter what side of the aisle and you have to admit --

SHAPIRO: But his own party has voted against in the House. There are Republicans who have voted -- yes, the constituents, and the men and women who represent all of us to Congress. But there are Republicans have given the president obstacles. You know, I am thinking of Floyd we don't need no education, we don't need no though control. It's just another brick in the wall. There are Republicans who are putting up obstacle, not just Democrats.

CASONE: And I grew up in two Border States: Texas and Arizona -- you can't tell me that someone is going to be more deterred by -- they will be more deterred by seeing 18-foot wall in front of a little --

SHAPIRO: My comment is not about right or wrong of the wall. My comment is there are Republicans who are as opposed to it and the president is going after the Democrats when he's got people within his own party who are saying not so fast.

CARTER: How are you going to pay for it? I think that's what they -- because they're holding up for it. Let's balance this budget, let's figure this out. We've got to make some short-term pain in order to, you know, preserve the economy, and that's what conservatives should be all about.

CASONE: Anyway, a great interview with Maria Bartiromo and Vice President Pence. We've really enjoyed playing you all of those clips this morning. We've got a lot more, coming up, so stay with us.

Paying your friends back could expose details of your private life; the shocking report that highlights concerns over the peer-to-peer payment app, Venmo, ahead. Plus, a new take on an old classic; how Harley-Davidson is shaking up its product line with the new electric motorcycle. That is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: Well, CBS' board meets today to consider whether CEO Les Moonves should step aside while sexual harassment allegations against him are investigated. Susan Li's got those details. Susan?

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Cheryl, this is the corporate story of the day, CBS has opened an investigation, after six women accused Moonves of sexual misconduct in a New Yorker story that was published on Friday. CBS' board also discussing the claims against Moonves over weekend. Now, Moonves says that he regrets any behavior that made women uncomfortable but says he never used his position to harm or hinder anyone's career. CBS releases earnings on Thursday, the stock which is under pressure in the premarket dropped six percent on Friday on concerns that Moonves might be forced to resign.

Meantime, shares of Caterpillar, CAT rallying in the premarket trade after the company's latest earnings beat the street's estimates and have raised its full-year guidance thanks to strong global demand. Caterpillar's adjusted profit blowing out expectations by more than $0.20. The strong results coming despite the threat of tariffs on the company's exports.

Now, it's a different story for Tyson Foods with the stock plunging in the premarket. The company is out with a profit warning for fiscal 2018, blaming increased tariffs and what it calls uncertain trade policies. Tyson will release its earnings on August the 6th, before the bell.

Four years, after unveiling its electric motorcycle concept to the world, Harley-Davidson is ready to bring the LiveWire bike to production, the company announcing this morning, that the bike will be ready to hit dealerships next year, 2019. And the LiveWire which was built with performance in mind isn't the only electric model Harley-Davidson is rolling out. Two middleweight electric bikes are slated for release in 2021 and then 2022. Harley-Davidson will even be making pedal-assist bikes as part of its new electric line up. Shares of Harley-Davidson are down though close to 13 percent on the year.

And, finally, my favorite story of the day, a heartwarming one out of Pennsylvania, a father working three jobs surprises his daughter with the dress of her dreams for 8th grade formal.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LI: After initially telling her that he couldn't afford it, the dad revealed a $200 dress while the daughter visited him as one of his jobs, and you can see the 14-year-old wearing her dream dress. The father is working at McDonald's, Popeye's, and a convenience store.

CASONE: Oh, my gosh.

LI: And I think he should be up for father of the year.

CASONE: Father of the year. Oh, we love that story, Susan, thank you.

LI: That was fun.

CASONE: That was amazing. (INAUDIBLE) Good dad. All right. We've got a lot more, coming up. Taking the extra steps to protect your privacy online, the new concerns over how much the payment at Venmo is exposing consumer's private financial information and nanny choices, that's coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: All right. Payment site, Venmo, at the center of a new controversy. A shocking report from a German researcher finds your purchase history can be tracked by almost anyone. And due to lack of privacy protections, this could be just the tip of the iceberg. Let's bring in The Cyber Guy, Kurt Knutsson. Kurt, hey, good morning.

KURT KNUTSSON, THE CYBER GUY: Cheryl, good morning to you. Why do we care about this story? I'll tell you why, because you can look up all these transactions that are publicly available on Venmo unless you have taken the effort to make that transaction private, or make all your transactions private. In the meantime, anybody can see what you've bought, when you bought it, using this payment service, Venmo, so why do you care? Well, the fact is if you can see that I'd buy a particular coffee at a particular store at a particular time on a -- on a habitual level, you could tell me that also -- well, that's a good time to go maybe rob my apartment or my house, or you might also be able to engage me at that point in a nefarious acts where you can discover when you add up our purchase patterns, you can add up what I might be at risk for in life. Let's say that I buy a lot of donuts on a regular basis, well, an insurance company may be able to buy that information and then suddenly, I would be considered a greater risk and would my insurance go up? You better believe it.

CASONE: It can raise your insurance premium, yes. We happened to have on set today, Erin Elmore who is the ultimate Venmo stalker it turns out. Listen to this first.

ELMORE: So, Kurt, first of all, to change these -- I don't want people to get too scared at home because all you have to do is swipe button, and then all of your transactions are private, so let that be told. However, two occurrences, one, if you go to your friends, say, hey, my friend Stacey has a really good nanny. You go to her Venmo and you see she pays Bethany for child care, I've seen people poach nannies and actually steal nannies from Venmo. Taking it one step further --

KNUTSSON: Right. And you find out what they're paying for the nanny so you may have an advantage to pay the nanny just a little bit more.

ELMORE: She pays $25.00, you say I'll pay you 30, guess who doesn't have a babysitter or a nanny anymore.

KNUTSSON: Erin, you are good. You are good.

ELMORE: Also, let's make it even worse, let's take this a little more (INAUDIBLE) for you, here. You could steal someone's -- you can find out if someone is cheating on you, your boyfriend or something. You find out, hey, so and so is friends with this girl. I don't know who this girl is, and then you find out on her Venmo page, they're paying for each other's dinners, sending heart emojis, kissing emojis. This -- you better turn the privacy settings on private or else you're going to have no babysitter and no girlfriend. You should be very careful.

SHAPIRO: Erin, we've got a new career for you. My gosh!

ELMORE: Cyberstalking.

SHAPIRO: Her private investigation skills are available online via Venmo.

(LAUGHTER)

ELMORE: But what do you think? Do you think these are really things that could happen to other people or am I just crazy with crazy friends and know a lot of cyberstalking skills?

KNUTSSON: No, I think -- I think this is a real problem. I think you're right, I think this is a real problem, and now that we've educated a lot of people on how to do this, fact is there -- what Erin is saying is correct, you can -- you can make your transactions private, but Venmo does no big favor to us to help us do that. They don't put that out front. And now, it's our job to tell you, you need to be out front with your privacy, they offer the ability for you to make one of your transactions private, or you can globally set all of your transactions to private, you could even go back to old transactions, and make those private, and that is what I would recommend you do. So hit settings, private, privacy (INAUDIBLE)

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: -- Erin stealing your boyfriends.

ELMORE: Or nanny. I'm a happily-married lady.

KNUTSSON: I'm scared now. She scared the bejesus out of me.

ELMORE: I'm a happily-married lady but I will steal your babysitter.

(LAUGHTER)

CASONE: Kurt, thank you very much. Good tips from you as always, Kurt knutsson.

KNUTSSON: Good to see you guys.

CASONE: Kurt Knutsson. All right, coming up, we've got final thoughts from our all-star stalking panel.

ELMORE: Oh, no, don't put it --

(LAUGHTER)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: Final thoughts from our all-star panel. Lee Carter?

CARTER: I can't wait to see what's going to happen with Trey this week. Italian meeting, the rest of the stuff that's happening this week. Trey's big deal.

CASONE: Oh, it's going to be a very big deal. Adam?

SHAPIRO: Once we get onto August, we're going to get the July unemployment numbers and look at the wage number. If you're year-over-year wage growth has not budged up from 2.7 percent year-over-year, it's a problem because that means wages are not rising as fast as they need to.

CASONE: Erin Elmore?

ELMORE: Make your Venmo private. That's it.

SHAPIRO: Special stalker.

CASONE: Erin can stalk you.

ELMORE: Doing it right now. Cheryl Casone.

CASONE: The best. Here we go, "VARNEY & COMPANY". Up next, Charles Payne in for Stuart. Take it away, Charles.

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you very much, Cheryl. I'm Charles Payne in for Stuart. We've got some real big stories for you today.

END

Jul 31, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) An email app created by developers who accused Apple and Google of unfair treatment in the past was just kicked off the latter's Play Store days after its creators went public about their cooperation with lawmakers in an ongoing antitrust investigation."If this isn't retaliation due to our role in the congressional hearing, then what is?" Blix cofounder Ben Volach tweeted Friday.The company's BlueMail app has been available on the Google Play Store for six years before the cofounders were alerted of the app's suspension Friday morning.Blix has also been kicked off of the Apple app store before in 2018. Apple later came out with an email product that was similar to BlueMail, prompting the cofounders to file a lawsuit against the smartphone maker in 2019.Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[1]. Google kicked an app off its Google Play Store after its developers contributed questions for the US lawmakers to use during Wednesday's antitrust hearing.Blix cofounder Ben Volach, who created the BlueMail app that was suspended, tweeted the revelation on Friday morning. Brothers Ben and Dave Volach both publicized their cooperation with the antitrust investigation earlier this week, as the Washington Post[2] reported."If this isn't retaliation due to our role in the congressional hearing, then what is?"

Volach tweeted. He also wrote "Apple & Google must be regulated. 2 gatekeepers to rule them all." —Ben Volach (@benvol) July 31, 2020[3] In a screenshot of an email viewed by Business Insider, the Blix developers were told by Google that its BlueMail app was now suspended after a recent review found it "not compliant with one or more of our Developer Program Policies." But according to the company, they were given "zero notice," a move that is "far too coincidental" considering the app is six years old and that it happened so soon after the hearing."Google either suspended BlueMail because we helped the House Antitrust Subcommittee prepare for the hearings or because Google just launched a competitor to Blix, our BlueMail for Teams product," cofounder Dan Volach said in an emailed statement. "Regardless, the fact that they have the power to kick you out of the store and cut your revenue stream with no notice is nothing short of absurd."The company also told Business Insider that a "lite" version of the BlueMail app, one that customers barely use, remains active on the store as Google apparently only took down the heavyweight version.Google later told Blix, per the Washington Post report, that the BlueMail app was suspended because the company found it to have copied another app."At minimum they should explain what the issue is, and not just remove it before the weekend," Ben Volach told Business Insider in an interview.The Blix cofounders have openly expressed their complaints[4] regarding Apple and Google and what they say is the two firms' unfair treatment of developers in their respective app stores."Apple and Google have no respect for their partners and they have too much control over our business," Ben Volach said in a statement sent to Business Insider. "It stifles innovation and tells the developer that it's not safe to bring new ideas to the store."Google and Apple did not immediately respond to Business Insider's requests for comment.Leading up to the hearing, big tech's treatment of third-party app developers was expected to be a major point of scrutiny, especially for Apple. According to Blix, Apple removed the BlueMail app form its own App Store in 2018 ahead of its Worldwide Developer's Conference. Apple later unveiled an email product that was similar to BlueMail, which prompted Blix to file a lawsuit against Apple over claims of patent infringement and antitrust violations. The lawsuit is still ongoing. urn:contentItem:5TH9-BVH1-F03R-N0T0-00000-00Developing markets drive digital payments boom, reveals report2018-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:58ZLexisNexisDeveloping markets drive digital payments boom, reveals report

Oct 17, 2018( Retailcustomerexperience.com: http://Retailcustomerexperience.com Delivered by Newstex) Oct. 17, 2018 Developing markets are driving a global boom in digital payments, according to the World Payments Report 2018 from Capgemini and BNP Paribas. However, the innovation landscape is uncertain as "BigTech1" entrants make their presence felt and incumbents face technical and regulatory complexity in developing collaborative payments ecosystems between themselves and fintechs.

More than bank-led initiatives will be needed to grow the new payments landscape, the report noted. The broader financial services community— including public-sector organizations, regulators and third parties —have to work together with large payment users to ensure a smooth, balanced and robust payments ecosystem, according to a press release on the report. Non-cash transactions are expected to post a compound annual growth rate of 12.7 percent through to 2021, following growth of 10.1 percent in 2015-16, which saw the total volume of non-cash transactions reach $482.6 billion.Developing markets lead growthDeveloping markets are driving the non-cash boom, with Russia (CAGR of 36.5 percent), India (33.2 percent) and China (25.8 percent) as notable movers during 2015-16. Mature markets maintained steady growth of more than 7 percent. Developing markets are set to post a 21.6 percent CAGR, led by Asia at 28.8 percent over the next five years. By 2021, developing markets are expected to account for around half of all non-cash transactions worldwide, overtaking the mature markets for the first time, whose current share stands at 66.3 percent.Big tech firms open e-walletsDisruption of the payments market is accelerating as new technologies take hold. In particular, e-wallets are on the rise and present a major market opportunity for non-traditional payments providers. In 2016, e-wallets accounted for 8.6 percent of non-cash transactions (a volume of $41.8 billion), of which 71 percent were facilitated by big tech providers. Although disruption is accelerating and market entrants are proliferating, there are regulatory and technical complexity challenges to the development of innovative new payments ecosystems. Only 38 percent of bank executives said they were "planning an anchor role"in new payments ecosystems. "As demand for digital payments is strong, especially in developing markets, some banks may want to revisit their choice to not seek an anchor role in the new emerging payments ecosystem," Anirban Bose, CEO of Capgemini's Financial Services and a member of the group's executive board, said in the release. "With their significant market share in the payments industry and implementation of new technologies, banks are in a unique position to shape the marketplace. They can also create new revenue streams through innovative, collaborative relationships with fintechs and active participation by the broader financial services community." Like banks, corporate treasurers should also consider their role in the new ecosystem as they expect value-added services that are safe, efficient, reliable and global and could co-design these services with banks. "Large payments users are also a key constituency in the evolution of innovation in the payments industry. Without their participation, payments services providers are missing a vital opportunity to shape new offerings in transaction banking such as in cash aggregation, cash forecasting and automated treasury," said Bruno Mellado, head of international payments and receivables at BNP Paribas, in the release. "These offerings could equip corporate treasurers with the means to move beyond a tactical or operational role and towards a more strategic one for their companies."Innovation faces complexitiesMany respondents said adoption of a real-time payments infrastructure was being inhibited by lack of interoperability between schemes (identified by 74.1 percent of executives) and weak data and authorization standardization (59.3 percent). Regarding distributed ledger technology, 85.9 percent highlighted lack of interoperability, 83.1 percent lack of regulatory clarity, and 77.1 percent ability to scale, as factors limiting adoption. The report also noted regulatory and industry initiatives are threatening to create conflicts as they spread from a regional to a global level. Conflicting KRIIs pose implementation and operational challenges that could hinder the transition to new payments ecosystems. Examples include the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive (5AMLD) and PSD2 conflict, as well as GDPR and PSD2. The World Payments Report 2018 is comprised of primary research based on executive interviews and an online survey. This edition also includes the introduction of the Payments Open Banking Assessment, which demonstrates the state of open banking in 16 countries from a payments perspective. From Hardware to Data, Verily Helping Local Companies Better Cater to Consumer Needs

ResMed and Dexcom are two of San Diego's largest medical device companies. They also share something else in common: a partnership with Verily, the life sciences spinout of Google parent company Alphabet.

The two deals seek to accomplish different things - one centers on hardware, the other on data - but they show growing overlap between health care and technology. Medical devices are one facet of the intersection, in which players must consider data-sharing concerns.

Dexcom makes a sensor that frequently transmits glucose levels to a smartphone, teasing out relationships between eating, exercise and blood sugar. It turned to Verily for help building a smaller and less expensive diabetes monitoring device.

But Verily contributed more than engineering support.

"They had a different perspective," said Dexcom CEO Kevin Sayer in an interview with the San Diego Business Journal. "We learned a lot from them."

The Perspectives

He said Verily thinks about things more from a consumer perspective, whereas Dexcom knows how to navigate clinical studies and the regulatory process.

The fruit of the partnership, Dex-com's latest technology called G7, will roll out late this year. Sayer said the company is scaling up its manufacturing footprint to meet demand for G6, its current diabetes system, and to prepare for G7.

Dexcom has been on a growth tear. In third-quarter earnings shared in November, the company posted $396.3 million in revenue, a 49% year-over-year increase. Net income came to $45.8 million during the period, according to the company.

Amended Deal

Last year, Dexcom and Verily amended their deal, which analysts said would improve Dexcom's profitability. Under the revision, Dexcom paid $250 million in stock to Verily, and in addition, Dexcom could make up to $280 million in milestone payments to Verily.

In exchange for these payments, the updated agreement nixed a provision in the original deal in which Dexcom would have paid royalties.

"We restructured the partnership to more accurately reflect each of our roles," Sayer said.

Verily, formerly Google Life Sciences, in 2015 announced diabetes as the company's first major disease target, drawn by a painful process.

Historically, diabetes patients pricked a finger multiple times a day to track glucose levels. But a few years ago Dexcom and competitor Abbott released technology that doesn't require blood draws for calibration, easing the burden.

In 2017, the total cost of managing diabetes was estimated at $327 billion, up from $245 billion in 2012, according to the American Diabetes Association.

As the dominant force in online search, Google's wheelhouse is data, artificial intelligence and analytics. But Dexcom isn't tapping that expertise - though it could.

"Over time that might be an avenue we pursue with them. That isn't the case today," Sayer said, adding Verily algorithms could potentially make care more predictive.

Option of Sharing Data

Sayer said Dexcom users have the option of sharing their data with outside parties. Notably, a recently announced partnership allows Dexcom devices to be synced with the diabetes management platform Livongo for health nudges based on glucose readings.

"Our patients own their data. We don't even consider us as the custodians of that data. It is our patients," Sayer said.

Companies must be mindful of data concerns given pushback in recent months over Google collecting detailed personal health data as part of a deal with St. Louis-based health system Ascension. Patients and physicians weren't notified about the project, dubbed Project Nightingale, according to the Wall Street Journal.

The newspaper confirmed in subsequent reporting that Google didn't break federal law, but the news stirred conversations about the ethics of medical data sharing.

A joint venture between ResMed and Verily only includes de-identified patient data, ResMed said in a statement.

The companies are researching and developing software to better reach millions of Americans unknowingly stricken by sleep apnea, in which breathing stops and starts, causing tiredness during the day and potentially serious issues like heart disease.

ResMed - which produces devices for breathing disorders - has amassed a trove of patient sleep data. Meanwhile, Verity's algorithm looks to produce data insights. Together, they aim to improve diagnosis, management and even the treatment of sleep apnea.

"Our philosophy is that the more a person knows about how much they suffocate every night and the consequences of that suffocation on their own personal health, the more likely they will seek solutions to improve their sleep and overall health," said ResMed in a statement.

ResMed Allocates $47.7M

The company has allocated $47.7 million to the 50/50 partnership. Verity's contribution hasn't been disclosed.

What made Verily interested in partnering with the likes of Dexcom and ResMed?

"We strive to work with preeminent leaders in scientific areas of interest to Verily, who have exhibited a solid history of preserving the privacy and security of patient information, and a commitment to putting patients first that mirrors our own," Verily said in a statement.

"While we will embark on our own initiatives, partnering will always be a core element to our growth strategy. We believe in the power of partnering with experienced, like-minded companies, which has at times the potential to launch initiatives faster than building from scratch."

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. I'm David Asman sitting in for Lou Dobbs. The Supreme Court today handing President Trump a major victory in his effort to combat national security crisis at our southern border. The court upholding administration's right to detain criminal illegal immigrants prior to their deportation. We take up the decision with Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton tonight.

Also, President Trump today meeting with Brazilian President Bolsonaro. The two leaders pledging the strength and ties on security and trade, promoting democracy and capitalism in the western hemisphere.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: There relationship that we have right now with Brazil is never been better. I think there was a lot of hostility with other presidents. His zero hostility with me. We're working on different military sites and military options, we're working on visas and going in a much easier fashion. One of the big elements of the relationship is trade.

Brazil makes great product and we make great products, so I think our trade with brazil will go substantially up in both directions and we look forward to that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: We take up the President's meeting with Bolsonaro with -- and what a close relationship with Brazil means for American security. The Daily Caller's Christopher Bedford, the Hudson Institute's Michael Pillsbury among our guests tonight. And the Trump economy still booming. The White House today issuing the President's annual economic report. For second consecutive year, the economy is out performing expectations. Council of Economic Advisers Chair Kevin Hassett today touting the administration's extraordinary successes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN HASSETT, CHAIRMAN, COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISERS: Getting a capital expenditure boom up about nine percent since the tax cuts passed and that nine percent capital spending boom is creating jobs and this year it's going to output and also continue. We can see that in order's data. And so the fact is that it's an old rule that I'm for economist that if you cut the cost to capital nine percent, then capital spending goes up nine percent.

And that's almost exactly what happened last year. And that's we're very confident, it will continue. I know --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: We take up the economy's strong performance and the positive impact to the President's tax cuts and deregulatory cuts. We are joined by Trump 2020 Strategic Communications Director Marc Lotter and Trump 2020 Surrogate Gina Loudon.

Our top story, the Supreme Court today issuing a decision making it easier for Federal authorities to detain criminal illegal aliens prior to their deportation. It's another victory for President Trump. Justice Clarence Thomas siding with the administration's effort to act unilaterally in detaining criminal immigrants writing, "I continue to believe that no court has jurisdiction to decide questions concerning the detention of aliens before final orders of removal have been entered."

The President is singlehandedly fighting for border security using his executive powers to declare a national emergency and then vetoing a resolution rejecting that declaration. Attorney General William Barr, a man of the law, not politics defending the President's national emergency declaration.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAM BARR UNITED STATES ATTORNEY GENERAL: The humanitarian and security crisis we have on the border right now is exactly the kind of emergency that presidents are permitted to address under the National Emergencies Act. The crisis that we're dealing with today is right on our doorstep and it presents a real clear and present danger to the American people. So what you've done from a legal standpoint is now that we grounded in law and from the standpoint of protecting the American people, it's imperative.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: The President also receiving another victory from the Defense Department. The Pentagon identifying nearly $13 billion that could be used to fund the President's border wall. The decision couldn't have come a moment too soon as tens of thousands of migrant families from Central America continue to try to enter our country illegally.
