LOTTER: And if the fundamental premise here is that when Democrats don't like the outcome, just change the rules. Whether it's the Supreme Court, whether it's the -- whether it's the Electoral College, they now want 16-year-olds to vote, illegal aliens to vote.

LOUDON: Illegals, yes.

LOTTER: Where do you -- where do they stop, what rule won't they change in order to get power?

ASMAN: Well, and again, Gina, it's not make America great again, it's change America to something that it never has been. I mean, that -- there are a lot of Americans -- I think there are people that -- even Americans who want change who don't want to change the fundamental character, the basic principles on which this country was founded.

LOUDON: But this is exactly why. You know, people are going to vote their pocketbooks, David, when it all comes down to it. As long as they feel safe which they feel safer than they've ever felt under this president, and as long as they have jobs and can provide for their families, those are the principles which they're going to vote -- under which they're going to vote.

And so everything that Democrats are proposing is a massive departure from everything that has been accomplished over the last couple of years. And so I don't see how the Democrats win unless they start to come up with some ideas that are not radical and that actually support the economy and the national security that we have established at this point.

ASMAN: It's going to be something to see. Gina Loudon, Marc Lotter, great to see both of you. Thank you for coming in. I appreciate it.

LOUDON: Great to see you.

ASMAN: Coming up next, President Trump sees Brazil as a top military ally in the Western Hemisphere. We'll have more on that when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ASMAN: President Trump today welcoming the new Brazilian president, Bolsonaro at the White House. The two aiming to strengthen trade, energy, and military cooperation. Trump even suggesting Brazil could be given NATO privileges.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I also intend to designate Brazil as a major non-NATO ally or even possibly if you start thinking about it, maybe a NATO ally. I have to talk to a lot of people, but maybe a NATO ally.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: And a critical Supreme Court ruling, Justices upholding the Trump Administration's right to detain criminal illegal immigrants prior to their deportation. Also, the Wall Street Journal reporting that former Vice President Joe Biden reach out to at least a half dozen supporters today to tell them he intends to run for president.

That's it for us tonight. Lou is back tomorrow. He's going to be speaking with White House Economic Adviser Kevin Hassett, Congressman Mark Green, and National Security Expert K.T. McFarland.

And at a programming note, my show "BULLS AND BEARS" airs every weeknight at 5:00 p.m. Eastern right here on Fox Business Network. We hope to see you there. Thanks for joining us. Good night from New York.

END

urn:contentItem:5VPY-H751-JBHT-D2CP-00000-00Devin Nunes Sues Twitter For Letting Users Allegedly Defame Him; President Trump Meets With Brazil's President; 'Wall Street Journal:' Joe Biden Tells Supporters He Plans 2020 Bid; China's Cyber Security Threat And Its Effects On Trade Talks; Elizabeth Warren Pitches Her 2020 Proposals Totaling $100 Trillion; 2020 Dems Call For Changes To The Electoral College; Dems' Radical New Ideas2019-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:58ZLexisNexisDevin Nunes Sues Twitter For Letting Users Allegedly Defame Him; President Trump Meets With Brazil's President; 'Wall Street Journal:' Joe Biden Tells Supporters He Plans 2020 Bid; China's Cyber Security Threat And Its Effects On Trade Talks; Elizabeth Warren Pitches Her 2020 Proposals Totaling $100 Trillion; 2020 Dems Call For Changes To The Electoral College; Dems' Radical New IdeasLanhamFULL TEXT

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. I'm David Asman sitting in for Lou Dobbs. The Supreme Court today handing President Trump a major victory in his effort to combat national security crisis at our southern border. The court upholding administration's right to detain criminal illegal immigrants prior to their deportation. We take up the decision with Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton tonight.

Also, President Trump today meeting with Brazilian President Bolsonaro. The two leaders pledging the strength and ties on security and trade, promoting democracy and capitalism in the western hemisphere.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: There relationship that we have right now with Brazil is never been better. I think there was a lot of hostility with other presidents. His zero hostility with me. We're working on different military sites and military options, we're working on visas and going in a much easier fashion. One of the big elements of the relationship is trade.

Brazil makes great product and we make great products, so I think our trade with brazil will go substantially up in both directions and we look forward to that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: We take up the President's meeting with Bolsonaro with -- and what a close relationship with Brazil means for American security. The Daily Caller's Christopher Bedford, the Hudson Institute's Michael Pillsbury among our guests tonight. And the Trump economy still booming. The White House today issuing the President's annual economic report. For second consecutive year, the economy is out performing expectations. Council of Economic Advisers Chair Kevin Hassett today touting the administration's extraordinary successes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN HASSETT, CHAIRMAN, COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISERS: Getting a capital expenditure boom up about nine percent since the tax cuts passed and that nine percent capital spending boom is creating jobs and this year it's going to output and also continue. We can see that in order's data. And so the fact is that it's an old rule that I'm for economist that if you cut the cost to capital nine percent, then capital spending goes up nine percent.

And that's almost exactly what happened last year. And that's we're very confident, it will continue. I know --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: We take up the economy's strong performance and the positive impact to the President's tax cuts and deregulatory cuts. We are joined by Trump 2020 Strategic Communications Director Marc Lotter and Trump 2020 Surrogate Gina Loudon.

Our top story, the Supreme Court today issuing a decision making it easier for Federal authorities to detain criminal illegal aliens prior to their deportation. It's another victory for President Trump. Justice Clarence Thomas siding with the administration's effort to act unilaterally in detaining criminal immigrants writing, "I continue to believe that no court has jurisdiction to decide questions concerning the detention of aliens before final orders of removal have been entered."

The President is singlehandedly fighting for border security using his executive powers to declare a national emergency and then vetoing a resolution rejecting that declaration. Attorney General William Barr, a man of the law, not politics defending the President's national emergency declaration.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAM BARR UNITED STATES ATTORNEY GENERAL: The humanitarian and security crisis we have on the border right now is exactly the kind of emergency that presidents are permitted to address under the National Emergencies Act. The crisis that we're dealing with today is right on our doorstep and it presents a real clear and present danger to the American people. So what you've done from a legal standpoint is now that we grounded in law and from the standpoint of protecting the American people, it's imperative.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: The President also receiving another victory from the Defense Department. The Pentagon identifying nearly $13 billion that could be used to fund the President's border wall. The decision couldn't have come a moment too soon as tens of thousands of migrant families from Central America continue to try to enter our country illegally. As National Correspondent William La Jeunesse shows us it's a situation that is overwhelming and already overworked border patrol.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: As the fight over the President's border policy continues, crews outside of San Diego just completed a 14-mile steel fence and started a second one. Stretching from mountains to the ocean.

RODNEY SCOTT, CHIEF, SAN DIEGO BORDER PATROL: This last year we've seen about a 700 percent increase in families and significant increase in unaccompanied minors here in San Diego.

LA JEUNESSE: This weekend 52 migrants rushed through a hole in the old fence. They tried to evade agents then claimed asylum when caught. Unlike Mexicans who are quickly deported, Central Americans take hours to process to verify country of origin, travel documents, medical condition and available bed space.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Between 25 up to 40 percent of the agents are assigned non-patrol duties today processing transport or care and feeding of these -- of the family units.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We are seeing increasing medical problem as they come across the border.

LA JEUNESSE: Smuggler also use children as decoys, dropping off this six and nine-year-old over a fence, while t 10 migrants cross illegally only a mile away.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We have to identify and then go apprehend every single person that crosses the border. Whether they're claiming asylum, whether they're smuggling narcotics or whether they're involved in human trafficking.

LA JEUNESSE: In a recent 73-day period, DHS released 84,000 immigrant families back into the United States. In San Diego, nonprofits their own shelter to help ICE handle the overflow.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It has been a non-stop flow of people from anywhere from 50 to 140 people a day.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LA JEUNESSE: The border fence stretched more than 650 miles when the President took office. Now he's replaced about 140 miles of that with this new style bollard fence. But he still wants at least 200 miles more either from the Defense Department or the 2020 budget. David?

ASMAN: William La Jeunesse, thank you very much. Well, President Trump meeting with Brazilian President Bolsonaro, where the two leaders pledged to work together, economically, militarily and socially to create a stronger relationship. Edward Lawrence has the very latest tonight from Washington.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINES NETWORK REPORTER: Well, David, President Donald Trump and the Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro talked about becoming closer trade allies, also becoming closer partners. President Donald Trump saying he wants to elevate Brazil to be a major non-NATO ally. That will open up opportunities for farmers. Brazil will now allow 750,000 tons of wheat tariff free.

In exchange the U.S. will start a process to Brazilian beef. The Brazilian president known as Trump of the tropics wants to try and open up his economic and spark a boom.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The President's vision for freeing the private sector and opening the economy is the right way for Brazil to achieve strong economic growth and our great companies are ready to go.

LAWRENCE: The relationship of the two presidents has grown because of the crisis in Venezuela, Brazil has helped the U.S. get aid to much needed people in Venezuela who badly need medical supplies and food.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Together we could and have been really very happy to feed thousands and thousands of starving Venezuelans. The Venezuelan people have appreciated it. And if the Maduro forces would step aside it could be a truly great and successful humanitarian project. We call on members of the Venezuelan military to end their support for Maduro. Who is really nothing more than a Cuban puppet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: President Donald Trump says that all options or on the table to get Maduro out of power. 50 countries -- more than 50 counties around the world recognize Juan Guaido as the legitimate president of Venezuela. Brazil has not always been the best partner for the United States, it seems to change now with this new president, this meeting, very important meeting kicking off a new era in our relationship. Thank you, David.

ASMAN: Edward, thank you very much. Well, we are learning new information tonight about just how long the Mueller witch-hunt has been investigating President Trump's former lawyer. For details on probe into Michael Cohen we turn to Chief Intelligence Correspondent Catherine Herridge.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: David, this heavily redacted court record show the investigation to Michael Cohen began nearly a year before the FBI raided his New York business in April, 2018. The Special Counsel requested and obtained multiple warrants for Cohen's e-mails that covered correspondents during the presidential campaign. The filing runs into the hundreds of pages and 19 are completely blacked out or redacted with the heading "Illegal campaign contribution scheme, underlying how the President's greatest legal exposure may be in southern district of New York and unrelated to Russia collusion."

Cohen pled guilty to lying to Congress as well as multiple financial crimes including campaign finance violations after two women were paged to remain silence about alleged affairs prior to the presidential election. President Trump denies their allegations. The unsealed court record show Federal investor s also wanted historical and future location data for Cohen's iPhones to confirm from where he sent and received e-mails.

In April 2018, the FBI sought and obtained authority to use an electronic technique known as Triggerfish. On Fox earlier today, a former Justice Department official said, the investigative strategy is not common.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES TRUSTY, FORMER DOJ PROSECUTOR: I think it's probably is geo location and knowing where this guy is which could mean that they're trying to corroborate on an important point or could mean they're trying to find out if he's lying to them about an important point.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HERRIDGE: The April 2018 timeframe may be significant because Cohen testified last month that he was told by U.S. attorney to not discuss his conversations after the FBI raid. David?

ASMAN: Catherine, thank you. Still to come tonight. Elizabeth Warren's ideas for America come at the cost of trillions of dollars.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), MASSACHUSETTS: It's time to start the national full-blown conversation about reparations in this country. We should make a big investment in housing. Medicare for All. The Green New Deal, I have got plans to reduce student loan debt. Universal child care, universal pre-K for every child in America.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: And it's all your money. We take that up later tonight with the Trump 2020 Campaign's Marc Lotter and Gina Loudon. But up next, Rod Rosenstein is still lurking around the Department of Justice. So what is he up to? We'll ask Judicial Watch's Tim Fitton when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ASMAN: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein has reached an agreement with Attorney General William Barr to stay on at the Justice Department for "a little while longer." Rosenstein who planned to step down in mid March is still main liaison between the Department and Special Counsel Robert Mueller. But it's Barr who has had main oversight of the probe since his confirmation.

Joining me now is Tom Fitton, the President of Judicial Watch. Good to see you, Tom. So isn't it about time for Rosenstein to move on?

TOM FITTON, PRESIDENT, JUDICIAL WATCH: Look, it seems to me that Mueller is still running the Justice Department, and the Attorney General has got to take back control of his Justice Department. Rod Rosenstein and Mueller have been working closely together on this abusive investigation targeting President Trump. Rosenstein is responsible for obstruction of Congressional investigations covering up which way he can, details about the abuses of the Justice Department and the FBI and targeting President Trump and others.

And it's just remarkable to me that the Attorney General continues to have him in place in this position of power. He is effectively running the Justice Department as number two. That's what the A.G. does. And by outsourcing control of the Justice Department to Rod Rosenstein, Mr. Barr is sending a signal that it's business as usual at the deep state.

ASMAN: How long do you think he will be there? I mean, it can't go on that much longer, can it?

FITTON: Well, I think they have nominated someone to take over his slot. So, you know, but it could be four, five, six months before that position is filled. So, you could continue to -- as you highlight at the beginning of the segment effectively collaborate with Mr. Mueller as he continues this presidential harassment campaign.

ASMAN: Meanwhile, we're learning a little bit more about the deep state and the witch-hunt through the Michael Cohen revelations. The search warrant was released. Can -- so much of it has been redacted. Have you tried reading in between the redactions to try to come to some conclusion about it?

FITTON: You know, I think the big takeaway of this is that you have the Mueller operation behind the abusive effort to impede on the President's attorney-client relationship with Michael Cohen. They immediately began dismantling that expectation of privacy that clients have for communication with their attorneys almost immediately upon on his coming into office Mr. Mueller. And then they outsourced it to the southern district of New York later but they weren't really fooling anyone because they were obviously operating as avatars for Mueller in raiding Cohen in that really unusual raid of an attorney.

You know, the President's attorney was subject to investigation. I don't think they had good reason to target him other than the fact he was the President's attorney. And again, Mueller behind an audacious attack on the President. I'll tell you, the Attorney General has to figure out what's going on there. And if I were him, I'd freeze the whole operation until he figures out what's up and down in terms of all the peculiar activities and corruption involved in the operation including Strzok, Page, the hiring and the firing, the FISA warrants.

Why would he allow that investigation to go forward given all the concerns about abuse of the -- of the Justice Department and the FBI.

(CROSSTALK)

ASMAN: Well, and the concerns now are boiling over in the American public. I mean, it's not -- you don't have to be a fervent Trump supporter in order to believe it's a witch-hunt. Now the majority of Americans do. They got the message, they understand it. I mean, there is enough evidence and there's enough push I think from the public itself to justify ending this, no?

FITTON: I agree. You know, the Justice Department was in court today arguing that states attorney, Maryland and other states had no business harassing the President on this emoluments clause, absurd litigation.

ASMAN: Yes.

FITTON: Yet the Justice Department seems to take the position they have the right to harass the President. And they can investigate him anyway they want and this Mueller report is being used as a way to further abuse the President, hanging it over him. And just causing worry and consternation about the operation of our government. Again, this is the Justice Department. The President under our constitution controls the Justice Department.

Yet the Justice Department is operating as if it's a fourth brand of government. And the Attorney General I think needs to fix that.

ASMAN: Well, despite all of this, despite all the roadblocks to success the President continues to chock up victories. The most recent with the Supreme Court over immigration was a close decision, it was a 5-4 but we read some comments by Justice Thomas just moments ago. What do you think of this decision?

FITTON: Well, it's a big victory for the rule of law. It's a case that goes to the Obama administration. So this wasn't even a Trump administration policy. Look, the left is attacking our efforts to hold up the rule of law and immigration by affording illegal aliens' rights, they're not due under our constitution. And in this case, they wanted aliens who were released to not pick up immediately by ICE.

Wanted to give them the ability despite having committed crimes for which they have been jailed otherwise to be free on the streets. And the court said no, the law doesn't allow that. And, you know, just because ICE gets around later to arresting someone who ought to be detained doesn't mean they give up their rights to detain them. And it's a common sense decision but the closeness shows that there is a legal effort under way to undermine the rule of law in immigration.

And I tell you, you know, a further challenge to this law may succeed with the Supreme Court. And again, it will be just open borders mania as a result.

ASMAN: Well, and as I said, it was -- I was disappointed it was as close, it was a win but it shouldn't have been a 5-4 decision, and yet -- and yet there you go. Tom Fitton, great to see you, my friend. Thank you very much for being here.

FITTON: You're welcome, David.

ASMAN: And we'd like to hear your thoughts on all of this. Share your comments and follow on Twitter @LouDobbs, like him Facebook and follow him on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight.

Coming up. Congressman Devin Nunes promises to sue more social media giants for political bias.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R), CALIFORNIA: This is the first of many lawsuits that are coming. We have to help all of these people accountable because if we don't our First Amendment rights are at stake here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: The Daily Caller's Christopher Bedford joins me next with more. But before we go to a break, a look at the U.S. national debt, $22.1 trillion and climbing. We're back with more after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ASMAN: President Trump today condemning big tech companies like Twitter and Facebook for their anticonservative bias against him and other prominent Republicans.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Thing are happening, names are taken off, people aren't getting through. You've heard the same complaints and it seems to be if they're Conservative, if they're Republicans, if they're in a certain group, this discrimination and big discrimination. I see it absolutely on Twitter. So some things happening with those groups or folks that are running Facebook and Google and Twitter. And I do think we have to get to the bottom of it.

ASMAN: Joining me now is Daily Caller News Foundation, Editor-In-Chief, Christopher Bedford. Good to see you, Chris. So where --

CHRISTOPHER BEDFORD, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, DAILY CALLER NEWS FOUNDATION: Good evening.

ASMAN: -- do we go with the bias in social media? I mean, nobody doubts, I don't think that they're shadow banning that goes on as much as they might protest and say it doesn't happen. Most people realize it does. It's clearly anticonservative but where do you go from there?

BEDFORD: Yes. So Twitter first started shadow banning people in an attempt to lower the impact that racist could have on conversation. And what goes back and forth on Twitter. And an investigation by Vice News which by -- is no one would ever call a conservative news outlet for sure found that this investigation, this -- the shadow banning by Twitter seemed to wrapping up a number of prominent Republicans including then Chairman Devin Nunes.

Now, they also found it didn't wrap up any Democrats, there was no one else who was in the Democratic Party who we shadow banned. And time and time again, we see this. With different search engines, with Facebook, with Twitter, and their response is always, well, hey, this was an accident, it shouldn't have happened. They never quite explain how it happened. And because there's a veil of secrecy around their formula which is kind of necessary for them to continue as a company.

They've been using that veil secrecy however and saying everything is actually a mistake. But over and over again, these mistakes only target Republicans, and this is a real cause for concern about what's going on and who is making these decisions.

ASMAN: Well, we do know a little of what's going on which is that some of the algorithms were either developed by or continuing to be use with organization like the Southern Poverty Law Center which views just normal Conservatives as dealing in hate speech and awful things that lead to violence which is not at all true.

BEDFORD: And the Southern Poverty Law Center does exactly what you said. They grouped in a ton of Republicans, conserved publications, Christian groups and said that these are hate group. And one part of their racket which is very lucrative racket is that they are parroted by left-wing press across the board. We've had examples -- for example when The Daily Caller most of their staff was docked which means their personal details or their parents' addresses or their phone numbers were put on the internet and these were retweeted by groups on Twitter.

ASMAN: Right.

BEDFORD: We reached out to Twitter on this and the first response we got was, this does not fit our examples of what harassment is. Of course that was just somebody in one of the offices who made the call, probably someone with a strong, strong bias.

ASMAN: Right.

BEDFORD: The time we got into San Francisco, we were able to get that shut down and get those tweets shut down. But the average person who doesn't run a media company or isn't a Congressman doesn't have that weapon to be able to pull in and actually make Twitter do anything to stop it.

ASMAN: Here's the interesting thing from my perspective as a journalist is that you could be discriminated against by the social media companies but at the same time use the social media companies to your political advantage and this is what President Trump already has been doing preparing for reelection. We remember -- I remember when Jared Kushner, his son-in-law was on the cover of Forbes Magazine after 2016 was hailed as a genius by Forbes for what he did, how he used Facebook in targeting particular audiences.

They're at it again, they're -- I think $3-1/2 million they've spent on Facebook just in the past three or four months. So, despite all of this bias, it's fascinating how the Trump reelection campaign it using it in order to pursue their political goals.

BEDFORD: They've been extremely successful with it, but look at some of the public outcry over this. When President Barack Obama used Facebook and social media, it was a victory.

ASMAN: Oh, it was a victory. Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

ASMAN: He was viewed as a genius.

BEDFORD: They had profiles, there were books written about intelligent this was. And President Trump did the same thing, there were calls to put Steve Bannon and other people in prison over this. They called nefarious. So, these platforms exists and they have huge amounts of power. Facebook is one of the biggest arbiters of where people read their news in this entire country. And when they use that power for ill it's very, very dangerous and it's very clear that all these social media companies are aligned politically and culturally against conservatives.

ASMAN: And as they were in 2016 but again it didn't -- it didn't stop the election from happening the way it did.

I got to ask you about old Joe Biden and his pursuit of the presidency it seems to be edging ever closer, but do you think he's going to be able to elbow out all of the energy coming from the far left, from the socialists and others?

BEDFORD: And he accidentally announced that he was running and then had to take it back.

ASMAN: Sort of.

BEDFORD: Yes, you know, (INAUDIBLE) he always said I'm the only candidate. Well, hold on a second, I'm not a candidate yet.

ASMAN: Right.

BEDFORD: Joe Biden seems to be the kind of politician and the candy enough politician that he would be able to push aside a lot of this. The amount of money he's raised has been pretty impressive already.

But the problem with Joe Biden is outside of President Barack Obama. He has not been able to compete very well nationally. His previous campaigns for national platforms of fizzled out very, very quickly when he was a side person to President Barack Obama who according to report, then he did very well. So, how he will do without this colossal political figure backing him up, he could fizzle out just as quickly.

ASMAN: And of course, all he has to do is defend the Obama record which when you compare eight years of President Obama with a couple of years of President Trump, it doesn't look so favorable when you look at the stats. I know they love to say how wonderfully he did but again starting from zero practically anybody could. He's got a tough record to defend and he's going to be forced to do so by President Trump.

BEDFORD: Looking at it objectively, I totally agree with you, but a lot of the Democrats wish and pined for President Barack Obama to be back. And anyone who would say we're going to bring it back to these golden years when President Barack Obama was in for seen, one of the most liberal agendas America has ever seen is going to get a lot of Democratic support.

ASMAN: Christopher Bedford, good to see you, Chris. Thank you very much.

BEDFORD: Good to see you.

ASMAN: Appreciate it. Coming up next, prosecutors in Florida offer a plea deal for New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft.

Plus, the U.S. and China are planning new high-level trade talks. We're going to take that up and more with China expert Michael Pillsbury right after these quick messages.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ASMAN: Welcome back everyone. I'm David Asman sitting in for Lou Dobbs. Some headlines we're looking at tonight President Trump's new pick to lead the FAA is Steve Dickson. Dickson is a former Delta pilot and V.P. of flight operations this coming amid growing scrutiny of the FAA after two crashes of Boeing planes.

Florida prosecutors reportedly offering to drop charges against New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft. In exchange, Kraft and all those charged must admit that they would have been found guilty at trial. Last month, prosecutors charged Kraft with soliciting prostitution.

And U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin travelling to China next week for trade talks. This coming after report the summit between President Trump and Xi Jingping may be delayed until June.

Joining me now is Dr. Michael Pillsbury, director of the Senate Center for Chinese strategy at the Hudson Institute, author and trade advisor to the Trump administration. Good to see you doctor.

You know, in the midst of all these trade negotiations and friendly smiles, shaking hands and everything, you have pretty disturbing reports like that report that was a Wall Street Journal exclusive of the Navy review of a cyber attack of one of our key new missile development programs which would go on our submarines around the world. This was -- they had now have details of one of the most secret missile technologies we have. How do you square that with these friendly trade negotiations?

MICHAEL PILLSBURY, DIRECTOR, SENATE CENTER FOR CHINESE STRATEGY: Well I don't think the trade negotiations are all that friendly, David. I think they've been pretty fraught with tension and the fact that Secretary Mnuchin and Bob Lighthizer are going over yet again, I think it's a setback.

But frankly with China, we have a strange relationship. We both prepare for war against each other. Our military officers write articles about how to win war against each other. But we also have this enormously complicated and rich economic relationship with each side investing heavily in the other efforts to decouple our supply chains with China. Usually just shouted down by Wall Street. So, it's a complex relationship and it's hard to take the temperature. Know how are we doing, are we friends with China today but then we're military enemies tomorrow? It's getting more difficult.

And President Trump is the first president to launch into this as you know. So now, there's much more attention to how what China only thinks of America.

ASMAN: Well, and you mentioned supply chains. One of the things that the trade negotiators are working on something called mandatory purchase orders. The Wall Street Journal again wrote something about this because chip manufacturers, computer chip manufacturers in the U.S. are worried that these mandatory purchase orders may force them to set up some operations in China.

PILLSBURY: That's right.

ASMAN: In order to fulfill those requirements of how much we sell to the Chinese. They're worried because they know in China it's virtually impossible to stop spying. And of course, they have some real key corporate secrets in ship manufacturing.

PILLSBURY: That's why I think the big news of the evening is the announcement confirmed by two sources to the Wall Street Journal that the secretary of the Treasury and our ambassador for trade are going back next week, this is pretty big news.

And also, the chip manufacturing community does not seem to like this idea of being forced to build more factories in China. So, some of the aspects of this trade deal apparently are coming apart, and to put them back together again is in everybody's interest. But I believe President Trump when he said at CPAC, I would had a pretty good seat when he said it. He doesn't really want a deal if it's not a good deal in the -- for the long-term of the United States. That's the issue we're facing now as we confront these new developments from China especially the spying on our military.

ASMAN: Yes, and then there is the odd case of the willing cooperation, apparently of some companies in particular Google to cooperate with the Chinese, not cooperate with our Pentagon, but cooperate with the Chinese in a way that could directly benefit the military. The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, no less, General Joseph Dunford spoke to that point last week.

PILLSBURY: Yes.

ASMAN: Let me just play a clip and get your reaction.

PILLSBURY: Very scary.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEN. JOSEPH DUNFORD, CHAIRMAN, JOINT CHIEFS OF STAFF: The work that Google is doing in China is direct -- is indirectly benefiting the Chinese military. But frankly, indirect maybe not a full characterization of the way it really is, it's more of a direct benefit to the Chinese military.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: Now Google, since that those remarks by Ggeneral Dunford has said, that's not true, we don't do anything that directly or indirectly benefits the military. Who do you trust, General Dunford or Google?

PILLSBURY: I trust General Dunford. I saw the denial Google put out just a couple hours ago again in the Wall Street Journal who are really earning a Pulitzer Prize --

ASMAN: They are.

PILLSBURY: -- for the coverage of China.

ASMAN: Absolutely.

PILLSBURY: But Google should be ashamed of itself. There's no doubt about it. This young man who quit Google and protests last summer revealed how far Google had gone, buying a place in China, buying a web site, beginning to help spy on the Chinese people. If they Google something like Dalai Lama or a particular phrase. Google's got a lot to apologize for.

ASMAN: So, I'm sure what you have seen what I've seen is I cover the markets I see any strong hint that some positive element has happened in these trade talks, the markets go up. If there's negativity, the markets go down. I do think that there is going to be a pop if there's some kind of trade agreement. You know, a market pop they'll see that as a positive.

Would you see that -- is it possible that the market could get it wrong? I guess is what I'm asking that's something that is viewed by them is very positive may in the end be negative for the United States.

PILLSBURY: Well, a really good trade deal obviously could be a thousand points on the Dow Jones be a really big pop as you put it. But a bad trade deal, that's what I'm worried about. That there's no enforcement, that the Chinese do what they've been doing the last month or so. They're passing laws and rules that don't have the word America in them. They say all foreign companies will be treated better or all foreign investments will be treated fairly. They're leaving out who started this, President Trump and America. It's kind of insulting what they've been doing with these new laws and rules. They've got to focus more on giving President Trump what he's asking for before this gets out of hand.

ASMAN: Doctor Michael Pillsbury, great to see you doctor. Thank you for coming in tonight, appreciate it.

PILLSBURY: Thanks David.

ASMAN: Coming up next, President Trump says the end of socialism is near.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The twilight hour of socialism has arrived in our hemisphere and hopefully by the way, it's also arrived that twilight hour in our great country. The last thing we want in the United States is socialism.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: We'll take that up and more after the break with the Trump 2020 campaigns Mark Water and Gina Loudon, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ASMAN: On Wall Street, Stocks closed mix. The Dow lost 27 points, the S&P closed flat, the NASDAQ gained nine points, volume on the big board 3.6 billion shares. Crude oil closing relatively flat at $59.00 a barrel, gold and silver also closing flat.

And the White House released its economic report proving the Trump economy continues to boom. Real GDP growth hit 3.2 percent throughout the first three quarters of 2018. $30 billion were saved through decreased regulations and the U.S. surpassed Russia and Saudi Arabia to become the world's largest producer of crude oil.

And a reminder to listen to Lou's reports three times a day coast to coast on the Salem Radio Network.

Well, Democrat presidential candidate Liz Warren revealing her unrealistic socialist proposals. And according to recent estimates, her grand proposals will cost $100 trillion. Warren socialist agenda includes the Green New Deal, universal child care, and slavery reparations.

Joining me now is Gina Loudon, Political Analysts, Author, and Member of President Trump's Media Advisory Board and Marc Lotter, Director of Strategic Communication for the Trump 2020 campaign, former Press Secretary to V.P. Pence. Good to see you both.

Marc, let me start not with Liz Warren's economic plans, if you pardon the expression, but with the President -- what the President has actually done with the economy. This economic report is incredible. He just tweeted out something about his economic efforts. He said, amazingly CNN just released a poll at 71 percent saying the economy is in the best shape since 2001, 18 years. Wow, CNN becoming a believer. What do you think of that?

MARC LOTTER, DIRECTOR OF STRATEGIC COMMUNICATION, TRUMP 2020 CAMPAIGN: Well, the numbers are outstanding. It's -- if we're finally starting to see in the polls what the economists and the data has shown for so long, that the low unemployment rate, rising wages, people are starting to feel more secure.

But one of the biggest Nuggets in that poll was it 42 percent of Americans, a plurality said that they are better off financially now than they were three years ago. Only 15 percent said that they were worse off. So it shows that this economy is working for everyone. And that's one of the -- going to be one of the key messages heading into 2020.

ASMAN: And Gina, the only way -- and I don't think even then you could buy into Liz Warren's solution, but the only way to buy into a solution -- a solution in quotes that that costs $100 trillion of taxpayer money, and I don't know where you're going to get that, is if you believe the economy is absolutely in desperate shape.

I mean, the worst shape, nothing compared to the Great Depression, I mean even worse than that. And clearly, Americans don't feel it so.

GINA LOUDON, MEMBER, TRUMP'S MEDIA ADVISORY BOARD: Well, if Elizabeth Warren and the Democrats who have become actually socialist, that's self-stated, that's not my implication, if they have their way we will be back in no time to the Great Depression. Every single thing that they are proposing is either so completely desperate, David, that it makes absolutely no sense. Or it's almost some ploy to just grab attention in headlines so that someone will write a story about them more so than an actual practical proposal.

Because everything that Democrats are saying is antithetical to this economy that the American people are enjoying. It's excruciating to watch.

ASMAN: And then Marc, you just do the math. I mean, she comes out with these $100 trillion worth of proposals, and then she says she's going to pay for with a wealth tax. If you were to tax a 100 percent of the wealthy in this country, you wouldn't get $1 trillion.

LOTTER: You wouldn't even come close.

ASMAN: So the point is that you've got $100 trillion here, $1 trillion dollars to pay for $100 trillion. I mean, people can do the math. Americans know how to do the math.

LOTTER: And when you break it down, just the Green New Deal so not the additional $7 trillion she's proposing on top of the Green New Deal, it works out to about $5,000 a month coming out of every household's personal budget. I think most Americans out there are would be shocked to say to look at their household monthly budget and then take $5,000 a month out of it.

It's just unrealistic. It's not going to happen. And that's why this election is not just about the results we were talking about, it's going to actually be a choice. Do you want to keep this going or do you want go to Socialism?

ASMAN: And then, Gina, you have the problem that they have with the Constitution. The United States Constitution which they want to change on so many different levels. Let's start with the Supreme Court. Now, they want to go back to something that was last tried in 1937 by FDR when he tried to pack the Supreme Court by increasing its number and turn it into a political body. Now it's being suggested as a real suggestion by Liz Warren, by Cory Booker, by a lot of Democrats.

LOUDON: But it goes right along with all of their other desperate power grabs. David, nothing they're proposing is for the sake of the American people. Do you remember when the Democrats were the party of jobs and veterans? Remember that? This has all changed now.

This is all a massive power grab and a massive vote grab with one basic underlying principle, and that is that Americans have decided they will no longer vote for Democrats and that Democrats don't know what to do to ever win an election again except to cheat or grab power away from the American people when it's unconstitutional.

ASMAN: Well, they want to change the Constitution. That's just the point Marc is that they don't believe in the Constitution. They think that it's flawed on several different levels. First of all with regard to the Supreme Court, the Electoral College, of course, is part of it. I mean, they want to change America at its core, at its roots.

LOTTER: And if the fundamental premise here is that when Democrats don't like the outcome, just change the rules. Whether it's the Supreme Court, whether it's the -- whether it's the Electoral College, they now want 16-year-olds to vote, illegal aliens to vote.

LOUDON: Illegals, yes.

LOTTER: Where do you -- where do they stop, what rule won't they change in order to get power?

ASMAN: Well, and again, Gina, it's not make America great again, it's change America to something that it never has been. I mean, that -- there are a lot of Americans -- I think there are people that -- even Americans who want change who don't want to change the fundamental character, the basic principles on which this country was founded.

LOUDON: But this is exactly why. You know, people are going to vote their pocketbooks, David, when it all comes down to it. As long as they feel safe which they feel safer than they've ever felt under this president, and as long as they have jobs and can provide for their families, those are the principles which they're going to vote -- under which they're going to vote.

And so everything that Democrats are proposing is a massive departure from everything that has been accomplished over the last couple of years. And so I don't see how the Democrats win unless they start to come up with some ideas that are not radical and that actually support the economy and the national security that we have established at this point.

ASMAN: It's going to be something to see. Gina Loudon, Marc Lotter, great to see both of you. Thank you for coming in. I appreciate it.

LOUDON: Great to see you.

ASMAN: Coming up next, President Trump sees Brazil as a top military ally in the Western Hemisphere. We'll have more on that when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ASMAN: President Trump today welcoming the new Brazilian president, Bolsonaro at the White House. The two aiming to strengthen trade, energy, and military cooperation. Trump even suggesting Brazil could be given NATO privileges.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I also intend to designate Brazil as a major non-NATO ally or even possibly if you start thinking about it, maybe a NATO ally. I have to talk to a lot of people, but maybe a NATO ally.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: And a critical Supreme Court ruling, Justices upholding the Trump Administration's right to detain criminal illegal immigrants prior to their deportation. Also, the Wall Street Journal reporting that former Vice President Joe Biden reach out to at least a half dozen supporters today to tell them he intends to run for president.

That's it for us tonight. Lou is back tomorrow. He's going to be speaking with White House Economic Adviser Kevin Hassett, Congressman Mark Green, and National Security Expert K.T. McFarland.

And at a programming note, my show "BULLS AND BEARS" airs every weeknight at 5:00 p.m. Eastern right here on Fox Business Network. We hope to see you there. Thanks for joining us. Good night from New York.

END

urn:contentItem:5VP2-WWS1-JB20-G29R-00000-00Devin Nunes Sues Twitter For Letting Users Allegedly Defame Him; President Trump Meets With Brazil's President; "Wall Street Journal:" Joe Biden Tells Supporters He Plans 2020 Bid; China's Cyber Security Threat And Its Effects On Trade Talks; Elizabeth Warren Pitches Her 2020 Proposals Totaling $100 Trillion; 2020 Dems Call For Changes To The Electoral College; Dems' Radical New Ideas2019-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:58ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTTom Fitton, Christopher Bedford, Michael Pillsbury, Gina Loudon, Marc LotterNEWSFinancial031901cb.229Devin Nunes Sues Twitter For Letting Users Allegedly Defame Him; President Trump Meets With Brazil's President; "Wall Street Journal:" Joe Biden Tells Supporters He Plans 2020 Bid; China's Cyber Security Threat And Its Effects On Trade Talks; Elizabeth Warren Pitches Her 2020 Proposals Totaling $100 Trillion; 2020 Dems Call For Changes To The Electoral College; Dems' Radical New IdeasDavid Asman, William La Jeunesse, Edward Lawrence, Catherine Herridge

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. I'm David Asman sitting in for Lou Dobbs. The Supreme Court today handing President Trump a major victory in his effort to combat national security crisis at our southern border. The court upholding administration's right to detain criminal illegal immigrants prior to their deportation. We take up the decision with Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton tonight.

Also, President Trump today meeting with Brazilian President Bolsonaro. The two leaders pledging the strength and ties on security and trade, promoting democracy and capitalism in the western hemisphere.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: There relationship that we have right now with Brazil is never been better. I think there was a lot of hostility with other presidents. His zero hostility with me. We're working on different military sites and military options, we're working on visas and going in a much easier fashion. One of the big elements of the relationship is trade.

Brazil makes great product and we make great products, so I think our trade with brazil will go substantially up in both directions and we look forward to that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: We take up the President's meeting with Bolsonaro with -- and what a close relationship with Brazil means for American security. The Daily Caller's Christopher Bedford, the Hudson Institute's Michael Pillsbury among our guests tonight. And the Trump economy still booming. The White House today issuing the President's annual economic report. For second consecutive year, the economy is out performing expectations. Council of Economic Advisers Chair Kevin Hassett today touting the administration's extraordinary successes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN HASSETT, CHAIRMAN, COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISERS: Getting a capital expenditure boom up about nine percent since the tax cuts passed and that nine percent capital spending boom is creating jobs and this year it's going to output and also continue. We can see that in order's data. And so the fact is that it's an old rule that I'm for economist that if you cut the cost to capital nine percent, then capital spending goes up nine percent.

And that's almost exactly what happened last year. And that's we're very confident, it will continue. I know --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: We take up the economy's strong performance and the positive impact to the President's tax cuts and deregulatory cuts. We are joined by Trump 2020 Strategic Communications Director Marc Lotter and Trump 2020 Surrogate Gina Loudon.

Our top story, the Supreme Court today issuing a decision making it easier for Federal authorities to detain criminal illegal aliens prior to their deportation. It's another victory for President Trump. Justice Clarence Thomas siding with the administration's effort to act unilaterally in detaining criminal immigrants writing, "I continue to believe that no court has jurisdiction to decide questions concerning the detention of aliens before final orders of removal have been entered."

The President is singlehandedly fighting for border security using his executive powers to declare a national emergency and then vetoing a resolution rejecting that declaration. Attorney General William Barr, a man of the law, not politics defending the President's national emergency declaration.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAM BARR UNITED STATES ATTORNEY GENERAL: The humanitarian and security crisis we have on the border right now is exactly the kind of emergency that presidents are permitted to address under the National Emergencies Act. The crisis that we're dealing with today is right on our doorstep and it presents a real clear and present danger to the American people. So what you've done from a legal standpoint is now that we grounded in law and from the standpoint of protecting the American people, it's imperative.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASMAN: The President also receiving another victory from the Defense Department. The Pentagon identifying nearly $13 billion that could be used to fund the President's border wall. The decision couldn't have come a moment too soon as tens of thousands of migrant families from Central America continue to try to enter our country illegally. As National Correspondent William La Jeunesse shows us it's a situation that is overwhelming and already overworked border patrol.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: As the fight over the President's border policy continues, crews outside of San Diego just completed a 14-mile steel fence and started a second one. Stretching from mountains to the ocean.

RODNEY SCOTT, CHIEF, SAN DIEGO BORDER PATROL: This last year we've seen about a 700 percent increase in families and significant increase in unaccompanied minors here in San Diego.

LA JEUNESSE: This weekend 52 migrants rushed through a hole in the old fence. They tried to evade agents then claimed asylum when caught. Unlike Mexicans who are quickly deported, Central Americans take hours to process to verify country of origin, travel documents, medical condition and available bed space.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Between 25 up to 40 percent of the agents are assigned non-patrol duties today processing transport or care and feeding of these - - of the family units.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We are seeing increasing medical problem as they come across the border.

LA JEUNESSE: Smuggler also use children as decoys, dropping off this six and nine-year-old over a fence, while t 10 migrants cross illegally only a mile away.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We have to identify and then go apprehend every single person that crosses the border. Whether they're claiming asylum, whether they're smuggling narcotics or whether they're involved in human trafficking.

LA JEUNESSE: In a recent 73-day period, DHS released 84,000 immigrant families back into the United States. In San Diego, nonprofits their own shelter to help ICE handle the overflow.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It has been a non-stop flow of people from anywhere from 50 to 140 people a day.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LA JEUNESSE: The border fence stretched more than 650 miles when the President took office. Now he's replaced about 140 miles of that with this new style bollard fence. But he still wants at least 200 miles more either from the Defense Department or the 2020 budget. David?

ASMAN: William La Jeunesse, thank you very much. Well, President Trump meeting with Brazilian President Bolsonaro, where the two leaders pledged to work together, economically, militarily and socially to create a stronger relationship. Edward Lawrence has the very latest tonight from Washington.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINES NETWORK REPORTER: Well, David, President Donald Trump and the Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro talked about becoming closer trade allies, also becoming closer partners. President Donald Trump saying he wants to elevate Brazil to be a major non-NATO ally. That will open up opportunities for farmers. Brazil will now allow 750,000 tons of wheat tariff free.

In exchange the U.S. will start a process to Brazilian beef. The Brazilian president known as Trump of the tropics wants to try and open up his economic and spark a boom.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The President's vision for freeing the private sector and opening the economy is the right way for Brazil to achieve strong economic growth and our great companies are ready to go.

LAWRENCE: The relationship of the two presidents has grown because of the crisis in Venezuela, Brazil has helped the U.S. get aid to much needed people in Venezuela who badly need medical supplies and food.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Together we could and have been really very happy to feed thousands and thousands of starving Venezuelans. The Venezuelan people have appreciated it. And if the Maduro forces would step aside it could be a truly great and successful humanitarian project. We call on members of the Venezuelan military to end their support for Maduro. Who is really nothing more than a Cuban puppet.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: President Donald Trump says that all options or on the table to get Maduro out of power. 50 countries -- more than 50 counties around the world recognize Juan Guaido as the legitimate president of Venezuela. Brazil has not always been the best partner for the United States, it seems to change now with this new president, this meeting, very important meeting kicking off a new era in our relationship. Thank you, David.

ASMAN: Edward, thank you very much. Well, we are learning new information tonight about just how long the Mueller witch-hunt has been investigating President Trump's former lawyer. For details on probe into Michael Cohen we turn to Chief Intelligence Correspondent Catherine Herridge.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: David, this heavily redacted court record show the investigation to Michael Cohen began nearly a year before the FBI raided his New York business in April, 2018. The Special Counsel requested and obtained multiple warrants for Cohen's e- mails that covered correspondents during the presidential campaign. The filing runs into the hundreds of pages and 19 are completely blacked out or redacted with the heading "Illegal campaign contribution scheme, underlying how the President's greatest legal exposure may be in southern district of New York and unrelated to Russia collusion."

Cohen pled guilty to lying to Congress as well as multiple financial crimes including campaign finance violations after two women were paged to remain silence about alleged affairs prior to the presidential election. President Trump denies their allegations. The unsealed court record show Federal investor s also wanted historical and future location data for Cohen's iPhones to confirm from where he sent and received e-mails.

In April 2018, the FBI sought and obtained authority to use an electronic technique known as Triggerfish. On Fox earlier today, a former Justice Department official said, the investigative strategy is not common.
