urn:contentItem:5SJS-BRP1-DXH2-6470-00000-00DexCom Inc at William Blair Growth Stock Conference - Final2018-06-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:58ZLexisNexis061218a11520212.712DexCom Incat William Blair Growth Stock Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Steven R. Pacelli

DexCom, Inc.- EVP of Strategy & Corporate Development

Conference Call Participants

* Malgorzata Maria Kaczor

William Blair & Company L.L.C., Research Division - Research Analyst

Presentation

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR, RESEARCH ANALYST, WILLIAM BLAIR & COMPANY L.L.C., RESEARCH DIVISION: All right. Good morning, everyone. We're going to get started over here. My name is Margaret Kaczor, I am the research analyst at William Blair & Companywho covers DexCom.

First off, I'd like to welcome you guys to the 30th Annual Growth Stock Conference. Our primary objective during these days of the conference is to present a variety of interesting investment ideas from our research universe. So these companies, both of which are relatively new and others that we've followed for many years, in our opinion, are a great representation of our quality growth philosophy. So we do appreciate your attendance and hope that you guys enjoy the conference.

Before we get started with our first company here, I just want to run through a few logistical details. First, you guys have a small booklet that you've received at registration. It contains the final agenda as well as room assignments for all the formal presentations and the breakout sessions. Second, with the exception of the last presentations of the day in which the breakout is going to be held in the same presentation room, the breakout sessions are all located on the seventh floor and specific room locations will be announced at the end of each of the formal presentations.

If you do have any questions regarding the conference, feel free to inquire at the registration desk or to any William Blair representative. In terms of disclosures, I am required to inform you that I personally own shares of DexCom. Beyond that, you can obtain a complete list of research disclosures or potential conflicts of interest at williamblair.com.

So before I turn it over to Steve and Matt, in terms of my preamble on the company, DexCom's been one of the best performing stocks in our coverage universe year-to-date.

And a lot of that's really been driven by 2 things: number one, competition to enter the market and despite a lot of fears that maybe with compressed shares, compressed price, it's actually not done that. In fact, it's expanded the market in terms of growth and adoption. Number two, the company received FDA approval for its next-generation sensor through an entirely new FDA regulatory pathway that should not only accelerate innovation but also keep DexComa step ahead of its peers in our opinion. So we think these are early signs over the next 5 years to push towards CGM is going to accelerate and whether that's driven by innovation, big tech, payers, patients, it should double or triple in size relative to where it is today, which is less than a quarter penetrated.

So we do find this to be an attractive market. We find DexComto be an attractive stock. With that, I'll turn it over to Steve and Matt.

STEVEN R. PACELLI, EVP OF STRATEGY & CORPORATE DEVELOPMENT, DEXCOM, INC.: Thanks, Margaret. I was going to let you actually keep going, you were kind of on a roll there. So good morning. Good morning, everyone. So what we talked about with Margaret, I'll probably do about maybe 10 or, maybe, 15 minutes of kind of high-level overview slides for those of you who are a little bit less familiar with the company and then we'll kind of jump into Q&A and then continue to Q&A in the breakout session.

Briefly, the safe harbor statement. So what you see on the screen here is that we've characterized the diabetes management ecosystem. You see companies play in many aspects of the ecosystem. What we have highlighted here in green is kind of the glucose measurement and the analytic side of the business and this is really where DexComis focused. We're the industry leader in continuous glucose monitoring. So we have industry-leading technology for continuously sensing a patient's blood sugar levels. And more recently, we've really delved into the data analytics side. So what you'll start to see from the company is not just continued leadership in the sensing business but also data analytics capabilities in terms of helping patients make better decisions to manage their diabetes.

From a drug delivery perspective, we've actually opted to partner with industry-leading companies, such as Insulet, the manufacturer of the OmniPod; Tandem, which is the manufacturer of the durable insulin pump. We work with all of the insulin companies who manufacture injectables, some are also working on insulin pump technology. We've chosen, at this point, though to stay out of the drug delivery business. Obviously, we're not a drug company so we began partnering with the insulin companies. And then on the service side, we're actually starting to do some exploration into how does our technology apply outside of just the intensively managed patients. So how do we bring our technologies into type 2 patients? How do we bring our technologies into the hospital, into gestational diabetes? And so you'll hear more from that in the coming months and years.

So managing diabetes is really a delicate balancing act. Patients are really trying to maintain a blood sugar in a target range without going too high or too low. When patients are too high, they're called hyperglycemia. These patients -- this is when they're experiencing -- they don't really feel the effects of hyperglycemia, but it's with high blood sugar, they're really causing all of the long-term chronic complications, the micro- and macro-vascular damage associated with diabetes. So when you think about cardiovascular disease, retinopathy, neuropathy, kidney failure, this is all caused by patients having elevated blood sugar levels. So the patients are constantly to take insulin, constantly trying to bring that blood sugar down into a target range. The problem is, insulin, once on board, is really hard to control. It's really hard to stop. If you over -- take too much insulin. And if they take too much insulin, they end up with low blood sugar or hypoglycemia. And it's really hypoglycemia is what patients actually fear the most, right? When patients are low, they start to feel a little clammy, they get -- start to lose -- you'll see them get a little sweaty, start to lose cognitive function. And if not treated, if they don't get glucose into their system, they can actually pass out on the floor. It's not uncommon to see a patient literally hit the floor. And if not treated then probably by an EMT, could end up in a coma and actually could end up dead.

So it's really trying -- that delicate balance that the patient is trying to maintain can only be achieved through continuous glucose monitoring. I can show you -- the unfortunate reality today, patients spend about 70% of their time outside of the target range, they're either too high or too low. It's a really, really tough disease to manage.

So historically, patients have used, to manage their blood sugars, a single-point fingerstick. And what you're seeing in this slide, is a day in the life of a typical patient. They would take 4 fingersticks. They're going to take a fingerstick, check their blood sugar at breakfast, at lunch, at dinner and then at bedtime. The problem is, this patient would look at the 4 fingersticks and actually come to some incorrect conclusions and think, "I had a pretty good day. Two of my fingersticks were actually within the target zone and my high for the day was a little north of 200 milligrams per deciliter, which is elevated but not terrible." But then when you overlay a continuous glucose monitoring trace, you see a completely different picture. This patient was above their target range for almost 14 hours. And more importantly, if you look about 4:00 a.m., this patient actually missed a dangerous hypoglycemia event. So this patient was probably still asleep. With continuous glucose monitoring, this patient would've actually been alerted to this low. Unfortunately, this patient during this portion of their clinical trial is actually blinded to the CGM data. So he didn't have the benefit of a critically important alarm at 4:00 a.m. So really, it's only by means of continuous glucose monitoring, not intermittent monitoring, that patients have the appropriate alerts and alarms to take action to manage their diabetes.

So this is where it starts. Our technology is really all about the sensor. As Margaret mentioned, the FDA recently approved our sixth generation product. Really, a step function for many of you who follow the company, really yet another leap forward in terms of our technology. We now have a sensor labeled by the FDA to be worn by patients for 10 days. The system no longer has to be calibrated and I can't overemphasize how important that is. So historically, our products require the patient to take a single-point fingerstick every 12 hours to calibrate the device. Now, the patient actually, with the new simple one-button inserter, click the sensor, push a button, sensor is inserted, pop in the transmitter. After a brief warm-up period, away they go, with no calibrations for a full 10 days. It's a remarkable user experience. It's a much more consumer-friendly user experience.

The transmitter on the body is much smaller than our prior transmitter. It's about 30% smaller than the prior transmitter. We've added predictive alerts. So I mentioned how important alerts are to the patient to let them know if they're crossing a threshold. Now we actually can predict up to 30 minutes in advance when a patient is going to either too high or too low so then they could actually intervene in advance of having a dangerous high or a dangerous low.

And as Margaret mentioned, as part of this approval, the FDA actually reclassified us. We followed a de novo process and the FDA is now actually down classified sensors if they meet certain special controls. And I can explain what that means. The FDA has established very, very rigorous controls. And basically said, if you can meet -- any sensor company, if you can meet these controls, you now qualify as a Class II CGM device. What this does is, this enables us now to iterate our products much more rapidly, while maintaining a level of performance required by the FDA that we believe is going to be very tough for any of our competitors to meet. So we were quite pleased this approval came in at the end of the first quarter of this year. Quite, quite pleased with the FDA and the work we did there.

So as I mentioned, the goal of the FDA is really to help us advance interoperability, and this 510(k) process is really designed to call it -- we're not classified as an iCGM or interoperable CGM. The goal with the FDA is to try to help advance our ability to interoperate with other technologies. So what you see on the screen here, as you see the insulin patch pump, that's an OmniPod, we're working together with Insulet to incorporate our sensor technology into the OmniPod. Working with the insulin companies, over time, we believe, be it DexComor the insulin companies themselves, we're going to develop technologies probably phone-based technologies to take our sensor data, their insulin data, marry those 2 together and really provide a much more holistic picture for the patient and really provide them key decision support help on how to better manage their diabetes. You see a Tandem pump there also making great progress with our partner at Tandem.

We extend that with the iCGM. What else can we do? We can extend the wearables. So we worked with Apple. We actually were announced by Apple as the first company they're going to let as a medical device display directly on the Apple Watch without having to use the phone as an intermediary. We're also working with Fitbit, working with Samsung on their wearable technologies.

We capture a lot of data. If you imagine patients using their phone to read their CGM. We're receiving 288 data points per day. We're capturing those 288 data points. With the patient's permission, we're able to share that data with other providers of decision-support, we can share with the doctors, with the patient, with caregivers. So wonderful work going on there, really opening up this architecture and really driven as much by DexComand by the FDA to open up this architecture and make this data available, really how the patient wants the data, who they want to share their data with and how they want their data displayed.

So today our market is really focused -- it's just the beginning, right? We're really focused today on the intensively managed patient. What I mean by that is, patients who have either type 1 diabetes or type 2 diabetes who have progressed to a point in type 2 where they're actually taking insulin at mealtime. There's about -- we estimate about 3 million total people in the U.S. and another maybe 3 million people in Europe that fall into that category. And that's for the foreseeable future, for the next several years, that intensively managed business is going to be the vast majority of our revenues. But when you look at the overall market, that's a tiny piece -- a tiny sliver, that intensively managed patient population.

Just in Europe and the U.S. alone, we estimate there are roughly 60 million people living with type 2 diabetes and we're working together with United Healthcare and with some other providers to really figure out how we can apply our technology in the best fashion and sort of think about almost like a diabetes prevention program. Patients will wear sensors, will capture other data, really work with the patient and the provider and the caregiver to modify their drug regimens, modify exercise, modify diet. And these programs are really in their infancy at this point. You're going to hear it much, much more about these in the coming quarters. But then our takeaway here is we're just in the beginning in terms of our market opportunity.

And then finally, before we open up to some Q&A. Our future is in miniaturization. Again, we're -- our core focus is always going to be on the sensor. We engaged in a relationship with Verily, which is the life sciences arm at Google, a couple years back to develop really some super miniaturized sensor technologies, really leveraging some expertise Google has on the microelectronic side, miniaturized radios, miniaturized batteries, data analytics capabilities to marry that technology with our core sensor technology. And so you should see the first products coming out within the next year or so with kind of what we call the home run product is probably coming in 2020. And that'll be a fully disposable, just a tiny little sensor that's worn on the body for up to targeting 14 days. The patient will wear that, insert it, it will talk to their phone and after that 14-day wear, they'll throw the thing away and put on another one. So truly remarkable, kind of game-changing sensor technology for us. And again, more on that to come in the coming quarters. So with that, I'll open it up to questions. Margaret?

Questions and Answers

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: Q

Well, I'll start out and then we'll go to the audience. But just to -- overnight and this morning, you guys actually had some news. So first, maybe on the CE mark that you received for the G6. How important do you think the G6 technology is for you guys in Europe? Could it help open new markets or what's the game plan over there?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: Yes. I think it's critically important. As I mentioned, our target focus right now is really on this kind of 3 million patients in the U.S. and 3 million patients in Europe who are intensively managed, who take mealtime insulin. The performance and convenience aspects of G6 is game-changing. Not having to calibrate the device, the accuracy, not having to calibrate, but maintaining a level of accuracy that far exceeds anyone else in the industry is critical. So I think the CE mark and our ability to roll G6 out in Europe -- we'll probably start in the U.K. and then kind of roll it out into the other markets. Germany obviously has been a big market for us in the coming months.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: Good. And the other piece of news was that you received approval for mobile devices for Medicare, which happened yesterday. So maybe walk us through that and whether that could increase interest demand or maybe even impact P&L a bit.

STEVEN R. PACELLI: Yes. So what Margaret's referring to is, we received Medicare coverage actually at the beginning of 2017 in a sort of a roundabout way. I don't want to go into the details now. It took us months to actually get to the place where we could put the processes in place to actually bill Medicare. Medicare has subsequently been a great market for us. But one of the critical aspects to our system is the ability for patients to use a mobile device, to not only to manage their diabetes by themselves, but also to share their data with a caregiver. So imagine a parent sending a child to school can no longer have to stress all day that the child is either taking fingersticks or who's managing their child, but the parent can be wherever they are as long as they're with their mobile device and could actually follow the kid in real time. Medicare, for some weird nuances in the way Medicare classified our system, Medicare actually initially prohibited the use of a cell phone. So we're quite pleased and actually we were at a point where we're having to tell Medicare patients if they were using their phone, we would obviously know, because we could track their data. We have to actually call them and tell them they have to stop using it or else Medicare would stop reimbursing for them. So very pleased. We've worked really hard and this has been a 15-month process. We worked really hard to push with CMS. And literally just yesterday, we announced that Medicare has changed the language in our approval so patients can actually take advantage of the mobile technology that we provide.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: I think there was a question in the middle over there.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes. What's the hurdle or what has to happen to get the other 90% of the market?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: That's a great question. So...

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: If you can repeat the question?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: So the question is, what has to happen for us to get to the other 90% of the market. It's a couple of things. I mean, first and foremost, we need to figure out what the right usage case is for the vast majority of type 2s. We don't believe -- so people taking intensive insulin like intensive insulin therapies, so meaning they're taking mealtime injections whether they're type 1 or type 2, have wild fluctuations in their blood sugar every day. So these are people who we believe need to wear sensors in real time, all the time. When you tick the -- per typical type 2 because they can't take an injection. If they're not taking an injection of insulin with or right after or right before a meal, it isn't as simple as just taking a correction to try to correct an excursion. So really what we're trying to do there is figure out how do we apply our sensor technology to this broad base of people to ultimately to reduce costs. That's what the payers care about. But really, how do we apply the technology, both sensor technology, I think, activity data, diet, exercise and marry all this data together and then really help the patient work with the clinician to either change their drugs, maybe hopefully prevent the patient from going onto the next most expensive drug. What typically happens today is, the patient will go on that format and then they want to see their blood sugars -- their average blood sugars will creep up, they'll put them on another drug and then another drug and then another drug. It's not uncommon to see type 2s on 5 or 6 or 7 compounds, very expensive for the system. If we can either prevent that next drug from patient from going on that next drug or, better yet, actually redo some of the drugs just by changing timing of dosage or changing their diet, changing their exercise, working together with their doctor could be huge. But we don't think that market is going to be patients wearing sensors in real time, all of the time. It's going to be much more kind of diagnostic programmatic, if that makes sense. And so still working through bringing some pilots we announced late -- early this year. A pilot of about 10,000 patients we're working on with United Healthcare to really figure out together with United how they've got the claims data, really how do we apply this technology in the appropriate manner and really bring down cost for the patient, for the payer, for the system. Yes?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Are you wearing a 6, Margaret...

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: I am now wearing a 6.

STEVEN R. PACELLI: I'm actually wearing a 6.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: I still have to get access to one first.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I'm sorry, but can you just walk through how you are able to do the recalibration?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: The recalibration?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: How you calibrate on the 6. How are you able to improve that?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: Yes. So the Gen 6 sensor, so it's a combination of things. Our technology really is kind of threefold. Let me characterize it as the core sensor technology that the chemistry that goes around the wire that sits under the skin. The algorithms that basically translate. So we measure at a very low -- we measure at picoamps, we measure an electrical signal under the skin, then we have to translate into a usable value, a number that the patient can read. And then the kind of the third most critical, another critical piece, is the ability to manufacture repeatedly. So -- and that's a critical component with Gen 6 to be able -- we've done some additional automation. So advancing the sensor technology, advancing the algorithms, but then being able to make these things super repeatable. So every sensor that comes off the line is basically the same. What you'll find with other companies, other competitors, some of their sensors work okay, others don't work hardly at all. And it's really -- a lot of it is lot to lot variability that they find in manufacturing. They just can't produce them repeatedly. It's kind of a combination of those things that just allowed us to get to a place where we knew we needed to maintain a level of performance. We were already with our G5. We were at an industry level performance -- industry-leading performance in terms of our accuracy. We decided, as a company, that before we would go to a no-calibration sensor, that we needed to be comfortable, that we could produce that level of performance in accuracy while eliminating calibrations. And we got there.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: Great. So maybe just to get back for a second to the G6. You had mentioned launching initially in the U.K. So maybe talk to us why the U.K. is the right market for you to launch there and why Germany's the right second market.

STEVEN R. PACELLI: I mean, the U.K. and Germany will launch somewhat simultaneously. To be honest, you have to translate the IFU and things like -- there's some work to be done to get it into Germany. It just takes a little longer. Germany -- the Germany and U.K. will both launch in Q3 and then try to roll out to the rest of Europe through the balance of the year.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: Does it change your reimbursement structure at all in any of these countries?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: Great question. It's kind of country-by-country. But the short answer is, I don't believe so. I think -- and we've kind of guided The Street that while we have the opportunity going from a 7-day sensor to a 10-day sensor to potentially pick up some additional price in terms of our modeling and our guidance, we're right now assuming that pricing is going to remain relatively stable in terms of going to a 10-day sensor.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: What's the pricing versus drugs?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: So pricing today, we're roughly, when you include the transmitter, somewhere between $8 to $10 per day. A typical patient on -- actually, I should -- historically, a typical patient is going to spend around $3 or $4 per day taking fingersticks. That pricing now has come down quite dramatically. So today, the fingersticks are probably in the -- maybe a patient spends a couple bucks a day. But again, hard to compare apples-to-apples, right? We're providing the equivalent of 288 fingerstick measurements per day plus proactive alerts, alarms. I mean, it's really difficult to try to compare the 2 technologies.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Will the G6 have to use a phone?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: No. The G6 does not have to use the phone. So there is a separate dedicated handheld, but the patient has the option to use either the handheld or their phone. We're exploring options where -- today, the FDA actually mandates that the patient have a receiver as a backup in case their phone dies. We're exploring with the FDA, they're getting more comfortable with the use of mobile technologies. To be in a place where the patient wouldn't have to buy if they don't want -- for example, I'm wearing a G6 today. I don't even have a receiver with me. I just use my phone. Yes?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: So you talked about the 2 big competitors that are in the market with you. And it's different things (inaudible). And I understand that, but they're very successful. Someone on Libre is unlikely to go with G6 because they're satisfied in that market because the people are more interested. (inaudible) training ground...

STEVEN R. PACELLI: Yes. I would say the latter, quite the opposite. In fact, what we've seen -- we've got much more experience with Libre in Europe, because they've been out for a couple of years. One of the big impediments we've had to adoption over the years is just the willingness of someone to wear something on their body, right? Because there's an internal transmitter, the radio transmitter sits outside of the body. What we found is that patients who try Libre, Libre is more cost effective to start than a DexCom but not nearly as feature rich. It's not a true CGM. It's an intermittent monitor. What we found though is, that patients are comfortable wearing, particularly in the reimbursed market, if patients are comfortable wearing something on their body, they start with a Libre, try it, and then they progress to a DexCom. So yes, it's actually the opposite. Libre's been quite successful. They've added a number of patients, or at least they had quite a few patients try the system, largely result of the fact that it's pretty inexpensive to get onto the system. In the U.S, for example, they have very little reimbursement, it's really just a cash pay product right now that they're kind of rebating down to make it a little more affordable for the patient. Our understanding is their attrition rates are pretty high, that the patients aren't really sticking to the technology. But as Margaret mentioned at the outset, we are seeing with the aggressive marketing that Abbott is doing with that Libre product, it really is creating a significantly greater awareness of kind of sensing as a category. And it's kind of a rising tide, it lifts all boats, it's been a great thing for us. On the Medtronic side, Medtronic is really a struggle. They just recently announced approval of a standalone sensor. We haven't really seen it much yet. It's going to be a sensor that, at a minimum, requires 2 calibrations per day to obtain any level of reasonable accuracy. What we're hearing -- seeing in their clinical data, patients are having to calibrate it closer to 4 times a day. So really hard to convince someone to wear a sensor, they have to calibrate every 6 hours versus one that you don't have to calibrate at all. So we'll have to see how that one plays out when they actually launch it.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: Steve, I think there's one in the middle here.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Yes, just what with -- from the perspective of the patients obviously (inaudible) effectively a generation of saying that. I just wondered (inaudible).

STEVEN R. PACELLI: Why would someone continue to use a strip? Either, lack of awareness, believe it or not, that they haven't been exposed to CGM. Economics is always a big one. I mean, there's still -- while we have broad reimbursement here in the U.S. and in Europe, there's still a co-pay associated with it. But I do believe now that we've moved -- the technology has progressed to a point where incremental improvements now in accuracy are probably not that significant because the patient is not going to be able to perceive them. But making it, like I showed you with the Verily product, making it smaller, just making the entirety of the system more user-friendly, more consumer-friendly for the patient, continuing to develop new and better tools to help the patient. But I think 20 years from now, you're not going to find anybody on intensive insulin using anything other than a sensor. I just can't imagine why you would.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: And then, Steve, you guys launched the G6, I believe June 4 was the right day...

STEVEN R. PACELLI: Yes, just beginning of June. Yes.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: So you're a few weeks in. I know it's extremely early, but it seems like you're actually marketing pretty aggressively already, or at least picked up the marketing spend. So maybe walk through why and what you see...

STEVEN R. PACELLI: Yes, we did -- if you read the blogs, we did more of a limited launch starting in May and the demand generation was just off the charts. Obviously, I'm not going to comment on the quarter or anything like that, but we've seen just the demand curve just go up pretty significantly on this product. People are real excited to get their hands on it. So it's still early in the full launch rollout. So we'll probably give better commentary when we do our Q2 call in 45 days or so but so far, so good.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: And then...

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Insurance companies reimburse?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: They do. We're typically lumped into the bucket of what they call durable medical equipment. So let's say, a patient is going to spend somewhere -- or a patient together with insurance is going to spend somewhere around 30 -- $3,000 to $3,500 per year, the insurance company is going to pay basically 80% of that and the patient will be responsible for about 20%.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: And Medicare will pay for the whole thing?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: So Medicare is a little bit different. There is a co-pay associated with Medicare. So Medicare is actually a bundled solution. So with Medicare, we -- basically the first month, we ship the handheld receiver and the first set of sensors with the transmitter. And then each month thereafter, the patient is on a subscription model. So we bill Medicare monthly, and we call the patient or email the patient saying, what supplies do you need as part of the bundle and ship them the supplies they need. It's actually a wonderful model. We would look to actually try to mirror that Medicare model if we could with some of the commercial payers because it's much more predictable and much more efficient for DexCom.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: And then the last question for me and I got to finish with this because last year at our conference I asked Kevin, what he saw CGM penetration was going to be in 2022? And I think he said 80%. But how has your thought process changed since then, whether it's changed to the space, the iCGM, the Libre approval, has that shifted at all relative to that?

STEVEN R. PACELLI: No. I mean -- I assume he is referring to type 1 patients.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: Yes.

STEVEN R. PACELLI: In the U.S., I don't know if that's not -- I mean, that is realistic, I believe. I mean, Libre is actually -- Libre has actually helped in terms of market awareness. I still think we need to -- while insurance does cover the product, I think we need to still improve access for patients. It's still -- not now, we're talking on the way in from the airport were talking about the patient who had like 15 or 16 interactions with their insurance company just to get approved. It's easier to buy a house than it is to get a sensor sometimes. So we need to improve access. We need to continue to improve the user-friendliness, the on-body footprint needs to continue to shrink, the performance characteristics. Again, I think we've reached a point where we're getting close to kind of a diminishing return in terms of improved performance, but if we can continue forward with some of the other feature sets that we've talked about, there's no reason that we can't achieve that level of penetration.

MALGORZATA MARIA KACZOR: Good. Well, with that, we're going to finish off here. And the breakout will be held downstairs, one floor in the Oak Room. Thank you very much.

Barr Says China Has Systemically Preyed On American Companies; NFL Player Kenny Stills Among Those Arrested In Louisville Protests2020-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:59ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTMichael Pillsbury, Victor Davis HansonNEWSFinancial071601cb.229D.H.S. Accuses Portland Officials Of Enabling The Mob; Woman Arrested For Cane Attack Of NYPD Officers; Crime Spikes Amid Calls To Defund The Police Nationwide; New Leadership In Trump Campaign As Bill Stepien Replaces Brad Parscale As Campaign Manager; Interview With Jim Jordan (R-OH); Roger Stone Prosecutor Who Quit Case In Protest Joining Facebook; Durham Probe Developments; A.G. Barr Says China Has Systemically Preyed On American Companies; NFL Player Kenny Stills Among Those Arrested In Louisville ProtestsLou Dobbs, Ed Rollins, Mike Tobin

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: A lot of headlines for you, and we hope you have a good evening. Again, thanks for joining us.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Good evening, everybody. For more than six weeks now, the City of Portland has been under siege by radical leftist mobs who are intent on destroying everything America stands for and the leftwing Democrat Mayor of Portland, eagerly supporting the anarchists, the leftwing activist and is permitting unchecked mayhem in the city.

Today, the head of the Department of Homeland Security tore into the radical Dem leadership in Portland for allowing lawless anarchists as he called them to destroy and desecrate that city.

For 47 straight days and nights now, leftist groups like Rose City Antifa and Black Lives Matter have plunged Portland into chaos. The leftist activists attacking citizens and destroying property and the Mayor just grins at it all. Law enforcement under constant attack, and today, the police had to step in to clear two downtown parks of demonstrators trying to create their own Autonomous Zone.

Businesses have lost millions of dollars because of the rioting and the looting, and Federal buildings, including the Courthouse have been firebombed and vandalized.

Acting D.H.S. Secretary Chad Wolf today said that, quote, "A Federal Courthouse is a symbol of justice. To attack it is to attack America." End quote. I would add, to attack a city is to attack America.

Federal D.H.S. and D.O.J. officers and agents have been deployed to protect the courthouse and other Federal buildings and to keep the mobs in check.

The radical Dems aren't happy about that. They don't want the Federal agents in Portland for obvious reasons, because the Feds, of course will protect citizens and they will protect property, and they will enforce the law.

How leftwing is the City of Portland and Oregon and their representatives in Washington and the leaders of their city and state? Well, a letter signed by Oregon's two U.S. senators and two radical Dem Members of Congress. The Fed's response was described by them as intolerable to try to protect life and limb and property.

Portland's activist radical Dem Mayor Ted Wheeler also claims it's the Federal agents who are causing all of the problems. There he is in all his glory. He wants them to just clean up the graffiti on Federal buildings and to allow Antifa to run rampant through Portland, to continue their rampage against law and order and the citizens of that city.

This isn't the first time, by the way, Wheeler has clashed with the Feds. In 2018, protesters created the Occupy I.C.E. Movement. You may recall that, harassing Federal agents for weeks. Mayor Wheeler cheered on the anarchists then, just as he does now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MAYOR TED WHEELER (D-OR), PORTLAND: To all demonstrators, I urge you to keep up this effort. We will continue to support the safe expression of First Amendment rights.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We invited Mayor Wheeler to join us here for full expression of First Amendment rights to join the broadcast, but our calls and our e-mails reaching out to this advocate of the First Amendment went unreturned.

In his statement today, Secretary Wolf summed up the situation, the crisis in Portland saying, quote, "Instead of addressing violent criminals in their communities, local and state leaders are instead focusing on placing blame on law enforcement and requesting fewer officers in their community. This failed response has only emboldened the violent mob as it escalates violence day after day."

And what we are witnessing in Portland is occurring across the country.

As chaos unfolds in Portland, the New York Police Department today has been making arrests after a high ranking officer and several others were injured during a protest -- one of those peaceful protests you know how those go -- a female arrested today. She is suspected of being the one seen here wielding a cane and hitting police officers over the head. The NYPD says the woman is having a psychiatric evaluation now at a local hospital but is in custody.

Some officers involved in yesterday's clash with protesters along the Brooklyn Bridge, well, bones were broken. They are receiving staples to the head to fix their injuries. Among those injured, the Chief of the Department, Terence Monahan, the NYPD's highest-ranking uniformed officer injured in this clash. This is how out of control things are in New York City.

At least 36 people have been arrested during that protest. At least one person was charged with assault. It is quite a scene.

The Trump administration has been intimating an announcement on how it plans to intervene in cities with a rise in violent crime and with, well, governments that are not responding to protect their citizens.

The President's decision to stand in solidarity with police, with all law enforcement has earned him a key endorsement for the presidential election from the National Association of Police Unions.

The officers they represent are dealing with what is nothing less than a massive rise in violence in their cities. Again, cities led by Democrats.

In Los Angeles, shootings have risen 28 percent. In New York, they're up 130 percent. And California's Governor, Gavin Newsom is planning to release 18,000 prisoners into the public by the end of August.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio has already released more than 1,500 prison inmates citing concerns about the China virus. And today, de Blasio even bragged about his city being a safer place.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MAYOR BILL DE BLASIO (D-NY), NEW YORK CITY: We now have fewer people in our jails than any time since World War II and we are safer for it and better for it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: That is borderline moronic to suggest that the way to get fewer people incarcerated is to simply release them from prison. But there you heard it from the good socialist, Bill de Blasio.

Recent data shows murders in the country's largest 25 cities are up 16 percent compared to a year ago. Crime has also risen in Minneapolis, as you might expect, where City Council members are working to entirely disband their police department.

Fox News correspondent Mike Tobin is in Minneapolis with the latest.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MICHAEL TOBIN, FOX NEWS SENIOR CORRESPONDENT (voice over): Following riots and public demonstrations against the Minneapolis Police, the city is now seeing a surge in crime. Homicides have doubled this year. Gun crimes dramatically outpaced last year.

People who live and work where the riots hits say prostitution, drugs and burglary are now unabated and they want help from the police.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It reminds me of Gotham City. So I'll call it the Gotham City of Minneapolis.

TOBIN (on camera): Because of what?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Because of the kind of lawlessness.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TOBIN (voice over): Members of the Minneapolis City Council made the announcement that they want to disband the police replacing cops with the Department of Community Safety and Violence Prevention.

With a segment of the public and the City Council against them, the police union says morale is terrible. Officers don't proactively police and are reluctant to use force.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SGT. ANNA HEDBERG, POLICE OFFICERS FEDERATION OF MINNEAPOLIS: Because any situation can turn violent. Something as simple as, you know, theft report could be an ambush situation. And you know, anybody might be out there to try to amp up a call just to put us into a situation where we have to use physical force and force hardly ever looks good on camera.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TOBIN (on camera): According to an attorney specializing in workplace disability claims, in the last six weeks, 160 Minneapolis police officers started the process of filing for disability. Most of those are officers who say they're suffering posttraumatic stress.

In Minneapolis, Mike Tobin, Fox News.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOBBS: Mike, thank you very much.

And coming up here next -- well, first let's take a look at Wall Street. Stocks finishing lower. The Dow Jones Industrials down 135 points. The S&P, down 11. The NASDAQ lost 77 points. Volume on the big board, moderate trading, four billion shares.

Crude oil down more than a percent, but still well above $40.00. $40.72 a barrel.

A reminder listen to my reports three times a day, coast to coast on the Salem Radio Network.

Up next, a major shakeup in the Trump campaign. Is this the change needed for the President's re-election victory? Ed Rollins joins us with that, next.

We'd also like to promote my new book, so here we go. "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever." Just to drive the left nuts, preorder your copy or copies. There's something they don't like about the title. I can't put my finger on it. They just don't seem to like "The Trump Century."

You can preorder at thetrumpcentury.com and drive the lefty nuts, amazon.com, Barnes and Noble as well. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: Breaking News now. Most voters Pennsylvania believe there is a silent majority -- a silent majority that supports President Trump's re- election.

The latest Monmouth University poll finds 57 percent say there are so called secret voters in Pennsylvania who support Trump, but don't tell anyone what they're about to do.

On Election Day in 2016, the silent majority was born out, FiveThirtyEight's polling average had Hillary Clinton up by nearly four points with a 77 percent chance of winning. "The New York Times" by the way, famously suggested 91 percent chance of winning. Trump beat Hillary Clinton in Pennsylvania by more than 44,000 votes.

President Trump making a change to his re-election campaign, removing Brad Parscale as his campaign manager, Bill Stepien now takes over in Parscale's place.

Stepien previously served as Deputy Campaign Manager. He is also the Political Director for the Trump transition team -- he was -- and a National Field Director during the 2016 presidential campaign.

Parscale will lead digital and data strategies as he has throughout and remains on as a senior adviser. President Trump tweeted, "Both men were heavily involved in our historic 2016 win and I look forward to having a big and very important second win together."

Joining us tonight to take all of this up, former Reagan White House political director, Republican strategist, Fox Business political analysts, the savant himself, Ed Rollins.

Ed, I don't see a smile on your face. You've been calling for Parscale's removal on this show repeatedly for weeks, and here we go. Did the move surprise you that the President made last --

ED ROLLINS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK POLITICAL ANALYST: It was a necessary move. One, you need to bring some intensity to this campaign. Bill is one of the top operators in the country. He worked for Christie. He worked for Rudy Giuliani. He worked for Trump. He was the White House political director. He knows politics. He knows how to run campaigns.

Parscale, obviously is a media genius, social media, but has never run any kind of a campaign before. The place was not intense. You could go on there anytime on weekends, nobody was around.

Yes, you need to have a campaign with the time that's left here, every single person that's working 12 to 14 hour days, seven days a week. Bill will make that happen.

Equally as important, Bill shouldn't report to Kushner or Meadows, he should report directly to the President and make this President get re- elected again.

DOBBS: Well, the understanding is that the President's son-in-law is in charge of the campaign and in charge for so many things, and he is the one who announced the change itself, which suggests that he will remain a strong voice over the campaign.

ROLLINS: He can be a voice, he can't run it though. There's a lot of things he is involved in that he doesn't know anything about and a campaign is something he definitely doesn't know anything about.

The people in the White House who know something about campaigns are Kelly -- Kellyanne Conway, who has been in many, many campaigns. She needs to get more involved. She's one of the top pollsters. She was a campaign manager last time.

I would get her involved and being a constructive force, not a destructive force. She's never been.

Equally as important, I would not be opposed to some of the people, Bannon and some of the others who were there last time coming in and being advisers or giving advice, not running the campaign, at least helping Bill move forward.

DOBBS: You know, I have a somewhat different view on that. Because Kellyanne right now, I mean, my gosh, her daughter is on social media, her husband attacking the President and has an organization behind it. It's a very difficult thing for her not to be a distraction, particularly if she were at the forefront of a campaign.

Let's turn to what this President can do.

ROLLINS: I think --

DOBBS: No, no. Let me finish. If I may, Ed. What is the one thing this President can do? What can he emphasize? Whether it's politics, a stratagem, whether it is people, it's a policy emphasis, what can -- what is the one thing you would recommend that the President do to assure his victory in November?

ROLLINS: Project strength. Everyday project strength. Focus on two things. Focus on getting to the bottom of this virus, helping state and local governments to battle this thing.

And equally as important, get us back to work. Get us back to work and get kids back in the school, and make sure that you don't chase rabbits. Don't be out there going after every little thing.

Obviously, the stuff that's going on in cities is important, but it's not the critical issue at the end of the day. Getting the economy going and getting these people back into schools and back to work is the critical thing. It's what he is going to be judged on.

DOBBS: Yes. Of course, the President was elected as the Law-and-Order President, and what we're watching is not just simply disorder and unrest in a number of cities. This is a wholesale attempt by the left, the Marxist left in many cases, to overturn this nation. It's extraordinary.

So, Ed, as always, we appreciate your counsel. You get the last word here. Good word.

ROLLINS: My last word is we're still not too late. Every week, we have to win from now on, though. He can't basically be sliding around. Get intense. The President has to take -- this is not the last campaign. This is this campaign. He's got to go win it.

DOBBS: All right. Ed Rollins, thanks so much. Appreciate it. We'd like to hear your thoughts on all of this. Share your comments. Follow me on Twitter @Lou Dobbs. Like me on Facebook. Follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight.

Up next, a former prosecutor from Roger Stone's case now setting policy for a Big Tech firm. We take that up along with a lot of other issues. Congressman Jim Jordan joins us right after these quick words. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Breaking news. The Washington Redskins who are changing their name have other problems. They've hired attorney Beth Wilkinson to review the Redskins' so-called past culture and what to do about it.

Two longtime Redskins executives fired earlier this week. Football insiders are expecting "The Washington Post" they say too soon publish a story on what is a blockbuster expose of the Redskins -- its organization and its owner, Snyder.

Well, also breaking tonight, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo says "The New York Times" 1619 Project amounts to an attack on the American way of life that aligns with and supports the Chinese Communist Party.

Pompeo said today, "They want you to believe Marxist ideology that America is only the oppressors and oppressed. The Chinese Communist Party must be gleeful when they see 'The New York Times' spout this ideology." Well certainly the left in this country is thrilled.

Former Federal prosecutor in the Roger Stone case, Michael Marando, leaving the Justice Department to join Facebook where he will be in charge of policy on social media content. Imagine that. The content I thought was generated by the users, but there it is.

Marando one of three prosecutors who quit the Stone case in protest after Attorney General William Barr overruled their sentencing recommendations, so we know he is quite an active little daffodil.

Joining us now, Congressman Jim Jordan, Ranking Member of the House Judiciary Committee and the House Oversight Committee. First your reaction, Congressman, if we may, to the appointment of Marando to being in charge of the content of Facebook.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): Well, I think he was wrong in his move with the Stone case, we'll have to see what he does. I do think it's interesting that the very day you bring this up, Lou, Twitter has kept me locked out of our account all day long. We can't, we can't post any tweet. And this is of course is on top of what happened two years ago where they shadow banned four Members of Congress.

Of course, they told us that it was just a glitch in their algorithm -- Gaetz, Meadows, Nunes, Jordan -- just a glitch in their algorithm. I said, well, you know, what did you put in the algorithm? The names Gaetz, Meadows, Nunes, and Jordan?

So why is it always that these big social media companies, why is it always conservatives who seem to get censored? The President, conservatives in Congress or conservatives anywhere. So that is my concern. We'll just have to wait and see what happens with Facebook as we move forward.

We do have a big hearing coming in two weeks, where the CEOs of the four biggest, you know, these four big companies are going to be in front of the Judiciary Committee.

DOBBS: Well, the best news I've heard in ages, Congressman, is that William Barr means to bring a full investigation, antitrust investigation of Big Tech. It's long overdue.

JORDAN: Yes.

DOBBS: The President promised it. And the fact is, it's gotten even worse since the President was elected.

JORDAN: Yes.

DOBBS: This is a country being run right now by the business, community, U.S. multinationals, Wall Street, and by the way, they're aligning not only with Big Tech and Big Business, of course, but Big China. And it's a serious, serious problem. They're creating policy outside of our government.

JORDAN: Yes, I would say one of the many good things the Attorney General, Attorney General Barr has done in his tenure, of course, he is coming in in two weeks for a hearing as well and he'll get asked about this issue and a host of others.

The Democrats I think will spend their time attacking him like they've done ever since he was named Attorney General. You know, they did file Articles of Impeachment against the Attorney General just two weeks ago. So that's another big hearing where we'll be able to talk about this issue, these big social media platforms attacking conservatives, censoring conservatives and a host of other things.

So we're looking forward to that. The Democrats have been out to get him ever since. I think it's amazing, Lou, ever since Bill Barr first testified in front of the Senate over a year ago, when he had the courage to use the appropriate word. He used the word "spying" when talking about what the Obama administration did to the Trump campaign.

And ever since he has used that word, they have been out to get him, but he just keeps pressing on, getting the truth and the facts to the American people.

DOBBS: The truth and the facts, they are slow to surface, aren't they? I mean, we're going into the end of the President's first term as President and we still don't have an accounting of Obamagate. It is outrageous.

JORDAN: No.

DOBBS: This President has been President throughout. He has been stymied. He has been blocked. And they've tried to overthrow his presidency from the moment he announced his candidacy almost.

JORDAN: Yes. All true. But we do have the facts and the truth that is coming out because of the work like folks and you and the handful of folks in the media who have pushed this issue, a handful of people in Congress and a handful of journalists around the country who push for this, and of course, the good work of Bill Barr when he was named Attorney General.

So we do have much of the facts and truth. What we don't have is anyone being held accountable. What we don't have now is this -- into this double standard, where there's one set of rules for us regular folk, but a different set if you were part of the elite political class in the Obama administration.

So that's what we need as an accounting and let's hope -- let's hope John Durham doesn't wait until after the election. Let's hope he gets his investigation done this summer, as Bill Barr said, just a few months ago, and that we ultimately hold people accountable for doing the terrible things that they did when they systematically targeted the Trump campaign, spied on American citizens, used a fake dossier that they already knew was fake as the basis to go get one of the warrants to spy on one of those Americans.

Let's hope Durham's report comes out and that there are people held accountable now.

DOBBS: You know, let's talk about Durham in terms of producing that report. Do you think he will those charges -- bring charges before the election? I have this horrible feeling that he won't. I hope so, too.

JORDAN: You know, I don't know. We want to a thorough job. We want a complete job, but as you said, it's been four years. Remember, they started July 31st, four years ago. July 31, 2016, is when they opened the investigation.

Here we are four years later, everything we've learned -- how they set up Michael Flynn, how they used the fake dossier, how they put this Mifsud guy was meeting with Papadopoulos, which starts the whole thing.

All of these things we've learned. In fact, I've said many times, I think I've said it on your show, Lou, that the only thing we had wrong about this whole sordid affair is it was worse than we thought.

DOBBS: Absolutely.

JORDAN: So let's hope that the investigation is complete and that people are held accountable and let's hope it happens sooner rather than later.

DOBBS: Congressman, always great to have you with us. Thanks so much for all you do. Congressman Jim Jordan, thank you.

Up next, Attorney General William Barr calling at Corporate America for their work for the Chinese Communist Party. Dr. Michael Pillsbury of the Hudson Institute joins us after this quick break.

And a reminder of my new book, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever." Liberals don't want you to know this, but it's available for preorder now at thetrumpcentury.com, Amazon, Barnes and Noble.

Order your copies right away. Thanks so much. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: Breaking News. "The Washington Post" is now reporting that 15 women who worked for the Washington Redskins are alleging sexual harassment by former scouts and members of owner, Daniel Snyder's inner circle.

The Washington Redskins have hired attorney Beth Wilkinson as we reported to you to review the Redskins organization and culture. Two longtime Redskins executives fired earlier this week, and "The Washington Post" now delivering the expos that had been rumored for so long on social media.

Attorney General William Barr today strongly condemning U.S. companies who are quick to bow to Chinese pressure and influence, saying the companies need to be careful or they might be charged as foreign agents. Barr said this, quote, "America's corporate leaders might not think of themselves as lobbyists, but you should be alert to how you might be used and how your efforts on behalf of a foreign company or government could implicate the Foreign Agents Registration Act."

Barr also warning the CEOs and business leaders about America's dependence on China, "Just as American companies have become dependent on the Chinese market, the United States as a whole, he says, relies on the People's Republic of China for vital goods and services."

"The COVID-19 pandemic has thrown a spotlight on that dependency," which includes all sorts of pharmaceuticals, drugs, medical equipment, and the list goes on and on and on.

Joining us tonight Dr. Michael Pillsbury, Director of the Center for Chinese Strategy at the Hudson Institute. Mike, great to have you here. This is this is extraordinary.

The Attorney General calling at Corporate America and Wall Street, not by names, but clearly Corporate America and Wall Street who are aligning with Chinese interests over the U.S. national interest. Your reaction?

DR. MICHAEL PILLSBURY, DIRECTOR OF THE CENTER FOR CHINESE STRATEGY, THE HUDSON INSTITUTE: Well, this is the most important speech I've seen yet by the Trump administration on China. I'll tell you a little secret about Attorney General Barr, his Bachelors and Master's Degree are in Chinese studies. He speaks a bit of Mandarin and his first job was at the C.I.A., analyzing China.

So frankly, Lou, he is the highest ranking China expert in the Trump administration. This speech is a blockbuster. He does give specific examples of companies. He's got a phrase I just love, Lou, that says China does not want to trade with these companies, it wants to raid these companies.

And he's got the power to prosecute. He has got a severe warning about people will get prosecuted if they don't file as foreign agents, and they go around and lobby inside the United States. He is talking about CEOs.

DOBBS: Well, you and I both know who many of those CEOs are. They certainly would warrant an investigation in my judgment. I don't know whether they would be guilty, of course. I wouldn't want to prejudge that.

But certainly, I would think it's fair to say, you and I both know who might be somewhat suspicious in that regard.

Now, China -- Xi Jinping is making it pretty clear that the friendship between he and President Trump is well over and that there is no backing up. This is a Cold War and the Chinese leader means to prosecute it.

PILLSBURY: I think that's right, Lou. I think President Xi sent out a letter today to what he calls the global CEOs. This is basically an interest group, including inside the United States that he wants to lobby for China.

So he is sending them an open message, to be sure and say, you know, these various talking points. It's really quite outrageous when the leader of the second biggest economy in the world starts forcing him essentially, coercing, Mr. Barr says in his speech, coercing business leaders to put pressure on their governments.

This is the Chinese way. In our country, it's five years in jail, Lou, for each count that you're doing this if you don't register with the Department of Justice.

DOBBS: Well, the Attorney General is exactly right, and we know that the Chinese have been doing this with greater breadth and with greater success over each succeeding decade for the past 30 years.

Now, they have maximum influence. The United States is, as the Attorney General points out in a position of maximum dependency and we cannot bow to the Chinese on any level, irrespective of what it means in the way in which we have to respond.

This administration is using the National Defense Production Act. We have to move away from that dependency and resolve it now. We are a great nation. This President has not asked this nation for much sacrifice. But this time, it's appropriate. We have to meet this challenge head on from the Communist Chinese.

PILLSBURY: It's a much stronger speech that F.B.I. Director Wray gave at our own Hudson Institute. He goes into detail, Lou, about Hollywood movies being censored to make money in China. It's got a very long list and specific examples and then he has the power to prosecute under various laws, including economic espionage.

This is a very powerful speech, Lou.

DOBBS: It's a powerful speech and now, it has to be backed up with action and therein lies the dilemma. So much rhetoric, so many speeches, so many promises from the Department of Justice, from the Department of Homeland Security, indeed, from our Department of Defense. I get the feeling sometimes that they are inert organizations who have no plan whatsoever to actually move to action.

Tell me -- tell me, I'm wrong.

PILLSBURY: No, you're not wrong. There's a lot of things that have been empty words. What I think is happening is the President's level of frustration with Xi Jinping is growing higher and higher and so he is looking for options of ways to get leverage on China and this speech has some of those options. There are other options coming out of the Senate. So we may be entering a period where you'll be a lot happier Lou, when the President is taking action, and it's not just members of the Cabinet giving speeches.

DOBBS: Yes, that is your expression. The fact of the matter is, it's correct. This administration, if there is anything that gives me great pause, that Washington has become a place where these politicians tell us what they're going to do. They tell us about their plans to do things. They talk about the problem very gently, and what they're going to do, and then nothing happens.

What is different this time as Barr is bringing great specificity to it.

PILLSBURY: Yes.

DOBBS: Talking openly and honestly with the American people about the dependency, about who the hell is facilitating Chinese interest in this country.

By the way, we've been talking about it on this broadcast for years. This is well known, or at least should be. It's just -- it is amazing that Barr has taken the lead on this issue. And by amazing, I mean, I salute him. I thank him. I know you do as well. This is so critically important to assuring the nation's security, and it is early in the process.

But it is -- it's begun where the administration is talking openly to the American people about our dependency, our vulnerabilities, and the threat that we now face and it is immense. You get the last word, Mike.

PILLSBURY: The only flaw in this piece, Lou, is he fails to footnote two crucial books, where he got a lot of ideas in this speech. One is your book, "Upheaval." The other book is called "The Hundred Year Marathon." That would have made it a perfect speech. And there are a few footnotes to this speech. It's very academic in some ways.

DOBBS: Don't mess with a scholar. Dr. Michael Pillsbury, by the way, I give the Attorney General carte blanche with whatever he would like to use at any time.

Thanks so much, Mike.

Up next, how badly will the NFL be hurt by their capitulation to the radical left? We take that up and more. Victor Davis Hanson joins us. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: Breaking news now. NFL wide receiver, Kenny Stills was one of 87 people arrested this week for protesting at the home of Kentucky's Attorney General, Daniel Cameron.

Stills was protesting the death of Breonna Taylor, who was killed during a raid at her home in March. Stills and those arrested now face felony charges of intimidating a participant in the legal process and faces as much as five years in prison.

Joining us tonight to take all of this up, Victor Davis Hanson, Senior Fellow in Military History at the Hoover Institution, Professor Emeritus of Classics at California State, author -- bestselling author, brilliant author, and "National Review" contributor and he doesn't do badly there either.

Victor, it's great to have you with us and turning to what we are watching, I want to put up a full screen that to me is stunning. And I think everybody in America should know this.

Let's see that Fortune 500 reporting -- the Fortune reporting on companies who've donated to BLM. Fortune 500 companies. You see those numbers? Those are pledges to the Black Lives Matter organization. Bank of America, a billion dollars over four years, PepsiCo $400 million; Walmart a $100 million; Apple, $100 million and Comcast. They are subsidizing a Marxist inspired organization. And for what reason? I have no idea. Do you, Victor?

VICTOR DAVIS HANSON, SENIOR FELLOW, HOOVER INSTITUTION: Yes, I do. I think that they do not want to Goya-type boycott. They don't want their franchises the objects of protest. They don't want people showing up at their executives' homes, so in their way of thinking that's a wise business preemptive decision. And they feel that given their bottom line, it's also a smart use of resources.

They have zero interest on the social stability and fabric of the United States. I hate to say that, but it's true. And so for them, it's just a straight cut business decision.

They don't know anything about Black Lives Matter. They don't want to know anything about Black Lives Matter. They don't want to know about its origins or its agenda. All they want to do is just make it go away and their usual way of dealing with that is money.

DOBBS: And they are not a nonprofit organization. They're also a Marxist inspired organization and they are behind much of the anarchy that we are watching in cities across this country.

I want to turn to an article by Victor Davis Hanson in the "National Review" and quote from that, if I may, and if you would put up the full screen of this so we can take a look and the audience can read along.

"If the multibillion dollar NFL decides that multimillionaire players have no obligation to stand to honor a collective national anthem, and that there will be separate anthems and politicized uniforms, then millions of Americans will quietly shrug and change the. And that silent protest will make the 2016-17 anthem protest look like child's play."

We're watching something here that is the NFL, it seems is on -- there's no question. This is a pivotal moment. Their future is on the edge it seems to me. If they move ahead with all that's been discussed, a new anthem, taking on all of these political issues on the field of play, they don't call it the field protest, as it's called a field of play.

Your thoughts about where you think we're headed, what will actually happen?

HANSON: Well, we know what happened in 2017. They lost about 10 to 15 percent of their viewership, both televised and direct fan participation and attendance, and that won't be anything compared to having an alternate anthem and then politicizing the jerseys with slogans, and this comes on the heels of a lot of anti-Semitic commentary that members of the NFL players have said, and their accolades.

And remember, Lou, this industry has been exempt from scrutiny. It's been a woke progressive industry that's lectured America on its shortcomings and it's lectured us about diversity, and it's got a real problem with diversity because of the 30 teams only, there's really not any white owners. I mean, excuse me, non-white owners, and that goes against the whole idea of diversity.

And yet 75 percent of the players are African American. There's only one percent Hispanic and less than one percent who are Asian. So basically what we're going to turn on Sunday, for those who would turn on the television is a very non-diverse ownership and a very non-diverse player profile lecturing America, how they need to be woke and more diverse and that's not a sustainable proposition or at the same time, you're lecturing America about its racism and it's illiberality and then saying, oh, by the way, we're multimillionaires and we want you, the middle class to keep paying our salaries and patronizing. It's just not going to work.

The NBA is doing the same thing, but where the NBA has an advantage it has lost -- it has about a 48 percent African-American audience, but it's lost most of its white, Hispanic and Asian audiences because it's even more non- diverse.

But what they've done is they've looked toward the 1.4-billion-person market in China. And so they've got a $6 billion franchising advertising gimmick to go over to illiberal China and be very careful about censoring any criticism of China while regaining their woke credentials by unloading on their own country.

But the NFL doesn't yet have that alternative to make up lost revenue with Chinese new cur.

DOBBS: Well, corporate and television sponsorship of both leagues is critical to their survival. One could almost, given your view, imagine the NBA moving to Beijing for its center of organization and headquarters. We'll have to see. You get the last quick word here, Victor.

HANSON: Yes. Well, I think in the case of the NBA, they've almost deliberately neglected any other audience than the young African American male viewer who is very loyal, but doesn't have enough numbers to sustain an average salary of $8 million.

So they're deliberately looking toward to China so they can maintain their -- I don't know -- their non-diverse politicized messaging to the United States that doesn't appeal to many fans anymore.

DOBBS: Absolutely. Victor Davis Hanson, always good talking to you. Thanks so much. Talk to you soon.

A reminder before we go to break, my new book, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History forever." Liberals take note, it's available for preorder now at thetrumpcentury.com. I invite you. I would even implore you to preorder. Stay with us. We're coming right back.

DOBBS: President Trump today on the White House South Lawn compared his agenda of deregulation to the radical policy and re-regulation plans of Joe Biden.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Our entire economy and our very way of life are threatened by Biden's plans to transform our nation and subjugate our communities through the blunt force instrument of Federal regulation at a level that you haven't even seen yet.

You think that was bad, you haven't even seen it yet. They want to go many times what they put you under in the past.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And that's it for us tonight. Thanks for being with us.

Citizens United President, David Bossie, Clay CountyFlorida Sheriff Darryl Daniels and Pastor Robert Jeffress among our guests tomorrow. Please join us and my new book, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever."

Good night from Sussex.

urn:contentItem:5N29-4G01-DXH2-647F-00000-00DHS: Illegal Border Crossings Drop in Trump's First Month; Ed Takes on Immigration Policy Analyst; Ryan Uses PowerPoint to Push GOP Health Care Bill2017-03-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:58ZLexisNexisTUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTAlex Nowrasteh, Rand Paul, Charles Krauthammer, Charles Krauthammer; Trace Gallagher; Omar Saif Ghobash; Dan LevinsonNEWSDomestic030901cb.260DHS: Illegal Border Crossings Drop in Trump's First Month; Ed Takes on Immigration Policy Analyst; Ryan Uses PowerPoint to Push GOP Health Care BillEd Henry, Trace Gallagher, Catherine Herridge

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Good evening. Welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT. I'm Ed Henry filling in tonight. Tucker will be back tomorrow and let me teased that you get to see a bit of him, later tonight.

For now, I am practicing my Tucker face or the Tucker look as viewers like to call it. But first, President Trump's critic said that his wall could never work. Well, the wall hasn't even been built yet but the mere talk of one may be having a big impact already. A new report says that illegal crossings at the Mexican border dropped big league as the President might say during his first month in office. In 60 seconds, we will debate someone who doesn't think the President really deserves credit.

But right now, we go live to our own Trace Gallagher who was crunching the illegal border crossing numbers. Good to see you, Trace.

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good to see you, Ed. The Department of Homeland Security says the 40 percent drop in the number of illegal immigrants trying to cross the border in February is even more remarkable when you consider that historically, border crossings in February rise by up to 20 percent. Look at the actual numbers here. In January, 31,578 people were apprehended trying to cross the Southern Border.

In February, it dropped to 18,762. That is the lowest monthly total in at least five years. And it also appears there was an all-out rush to get into the U.S. before Donald Trump's executive orders on immigration. Because in the three months prior to the inauguration, border agents apprehended 157,000 illegal immigrants. That's up 35 percent from the previous year. Then as soon as Trump took office, apprehensions plummeted.

Customs and Border Protection says, "This is good news for those who did not try to cross the border because they didn't put themselves and their families at risk of quote, exploitation, assault and injury by human traffickers" and the physical dangers of the treacherous journey north." Human traffickers by the way have increased their fees more than 100 percent in just the past 14 months -- Ed.

HENRY: Trace, thank you. We will see you later this hour. So, it's only one month but it appears that illegal immigration dropped. So why is our first guest so reluctant to give President Trump some credit?

Alex Nowrasteh is an immigration policy analyst for the CATO Institute, a libertarian Think Tank, he joins us live. So, repeat after me, some good news.

ALEX NOWRASTEH, IMMIGRATION POLICY ANALYST, CATO INSTITUTE: It is some news. The President --

HENRY: You said some news, some good news.

NOWRASTEH: It's some news. I mean, it's good and bad.

HENRY: Illegal immigration went down.

NOWRASTEH: Yes. But it might be for very good reasons that are good or bad.

HENRY: That's good news.

NOWRASTEH: The economy is not attracting them enough which is bad news for the American economy.

HENRY: But less illegals are coming to America.

NOWRASTEH: Right. Yes.

HENRY: Good news?

NOWRASTEH: Sure. Yes. Absolutely. But it depends why it's going on. Is it going on because we spent a lot more money at the border and wasting a lot of money on border bureaucrats? Or is it going down because the US economy is not attracting them anymore, that could be bad.

HENRY: Okay. So, let's get to that. So, before the inauguration -- as you heard Trace report.

NOWRASTEH: Uh-hm.

HENRY: Fair and balanced, he had the facts. Before the inauguration of Donald Trump --

NOWRASTEH: Uh-hm.

HENRY: There was a surge of people trying to get across the border. Illegals trying to get to America. They were afraid of Donald Trump building the wall and his rhetoric. Right?

NOWRASTEH: There was also a surge prior to the election going on in the first place. Well, the numbers throughout 2015 more above those of 2015 and the numbers in 2015 --

HENRY: Okay. We'll get to those. I promise I'll let you make all those points, let's just talk about the points. The actual question I asked you.

NOWRASTEH: Yes.

HENRY: Before the inaugural, there was a surge in illegals trying to get across the border before Donald Trump, took office, true?

NOWRASTEH: Yes. That is true.

HENRY: Okay. So, they were afraid that he was actually going to crack down on them.

NOWRASTEH: Well, as I've said, the surge --

HENRY: I'll let you go back to 2015 but let's talk about the reality print

NOWRASTEH: Before the election even occurred and the continued after the election occurred.

HENRY: Okay. But again, I just want to establish --

NOWRASTEH: I'm trying to say that it's attributable entirely to Donald Trump.

HENRY: When you say entirely, I said it was good news that illegal immigration has started to drop.

NOWRASTEH: Yes. And -- agreeing with you about that of course.

HENRY: Okay. And so, fast-forward, month one of the Trump administration --

NOWRASTEH: Uh-hm.

HENRY: All of a sudden, Trace says in terms of apprehensions at the border is the lowest total in five years.

NOWRASTEH: It's actually the lowest total in 17 years. I mean, if you take a look at the months going back to the year 2000, it is of course only one month and it's been one month since the President --

HENRY: And it can change, because you're right about that part.

NOWRASTEH: Yes. One month.

HENRY: It's only one month. You're saying it's even better than Trace said. You're saying that it's the lowest total of apprehensions at the border, meaning less people trying to cross, getting caught trying to cross in 17 years. That's good news.
